description:
Let's start by saying this is the only  Vietnamese spot that serves Thai Chili Peppers with the Pho and it's a game changer.
I created my own bowl with the roast pork, this dish was served with salad, been sprouts, noodles, mushrooms and a hand full of veggies.
The service was great and this place is really clean. 
I'd definitely go back to this spot.
author: Enrique O.

description:
Solidly average dining experience. TLDR; good atmosphere, food was ok 

In terms of apps, the roti was good though the garlic sauce was quite strong (careful not to scoop too much as I generally do with dipping sauces), the chicken skewer was actually very good, but the buns were disappointing. Papaya salad was not what I expected... was very dry and lacked much flavor. 

As for entrees, well the pho was... pho. Can't say it had much going for it, but it was inoffensive. The combination stir fry was about as good as a regular Chinese takeout, which certainly isn't bad but probably not worth the price tag here.

The atmosphere and decor is quite nice, and probably the best part of the restaurant. Likely won't be coming back for the food though.
author: Allison X.

description:
This is decent Vietnamese food and certainly a cute spot with respect to size / decor, but I would definitely treat this as a "neighborhood spot" - come here if you live around here, but don't travel out of your way for it.

Last night, two of us split the roti with curry sauce, wicked buns, garlic herb noodles, a special sausage appetizer (not on the online menu), and the basa fish claypot.  There was an attempt to also have the crispy rolls, but the waiter sort of messed that up, per the below...  All of the food was fine to good.  The roti was really tasty, though the curry sauce was sort of too sweet and grainy (not sure why re: texture).  The wicked buns were OK, but they could have used some mayo or spice to balance out the sweet glaze on the meat, and the buns themselves were a bit stale / hard.  The garlic noodles were also on the sweet side, and not terribly garlic-y.  They were also lukewarm, at best.  The sausage was....again...kind of sweet and generally fairly bland, and it was served with an even sweeter sauce that neither of us liked.  Finally, the claypot was ALSO sweet, but at least in this case I was expecting that.  

Man, looking back now....this was a very "sweet" dinner.  I think everything could have used more spice or something umami, like more fish sauce?  But it was all edible, just not amazing.  I think the fish was the best part and it seems to be their most popular dish, so if I did go back, I'd probably order that again.

Service was....not amazing.  At around 8:30pm on a Wednesday, the service was overly-harried given how (not) busy they were.  The restaurant was about half full and I didn't see any type of to-go / delivery orders being sent out, so I'm not sure why the staff was so neglectful of their tables.  The person who took our order not only messed it up (he apparently put in our full order, but then decided that he had gotten it wrong....even though he had not...and sent one of our items back to the kitchen???), but he also never came back to help us ever again.  We were waited on, for the rest of the evening, by a quasi waiter / quasi host that seemed completely overwhelmed...and his version of waiting on us was purely dropping off food.  No one asked us how we were, did we want another round of drinks, etc.  I probably would have ordered a second glass of wine if I were able to flag someone down.  As it was, we didn't get any place settings / utensils until after our first dish had arrived.

I will say that they have a pretty impressively broad wine/beer/sake selection for a restaurant this small and they've laid their wine list out in an interesting way, though I wasn't blown away by any particular wine option.

Again, this is certainly a step above a lot of processed, Americanized Vietnamese food that you can find, and a cute neighborhood spot for dinner....but not worth a special trip.  Maybe not worth a trip, at all, if you prefer spicy food...
author: Tay H.

description: this spot in San Fran is really chic and I'm surprised  it wasn't super busy inside. The decor was fantastic and owner? Was phenomenal! We tried multiple dishes like Bo luc lac, pho filet mignon, clay pot fish, beef carpaccio, and a few other dishes and none disappointed us. If you're local or visiting San Fran give this place a shot and you won't be disappointed!
author: Bradley H.

description:
I've ordered Co Nam from Uber Eats a couple times now in hopes of really good Vietnamese food but, have had two underwhelming experiences. 

The pho ga I recently had delivered was pretty meh. The slices of chicken breast were tough and felt like an afterthought. The broth itself was pretty good but, all in all just felt like standard chicken stock. Plus, they don't give you hoisin sauce or sriracha to flavor things up a bit...kinda weird. I also had a bit of the noodle bowl with chicken thigh that my friend ordered and it was very much the same as described above. 

Plenty of better options out there for those of you who are looking for authentic Vietnamese cuisine.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
I got the basa claypot and rice. The basa claypot was literally just basa fish, no veggies or other accompaniments. The fish texture was flaky, though it could have been a bit more moist. It felt extremely healthy. While the sauce (soy + fish sauce combo) could have been a bit lighter, given that the inside of the fish wasn't marinated, it worked out ok. 

The brown rice I got was rather dry and didn't have that nuttiness that makes brown rice so satisfying. 

3.25/5 on taste, but quite expensive for what it was.
author: Nicole H.

description:
I've always noticed this place in the neighborhood, so I decided to try it one afternoon for lunch.  Initially it took a few minutes for the waiter to notice us to be seated and the dining area was really dark.  I would say this place looked a lot more upscale compared to the typical pho restaurants I typically go to.  

I ordered the wicked pork buns and the beef pho.  The buns were tasty with a good combination of pickled veggies and tender pork belly.  The pho broth tasted good, but I couldn't help notice that I didn't get much beef.  I also liked the availability of Thai chilis to spice up my soup, but my eyes and mouth regretted it later. 

Overall, this place was pretty good and I'd give this place more of a 3.75.  Food was solid, but I can't justify getting a $20 bowl of pho very often.
author: Mitch T.

description:
2.5 STARS

For my office lunch main, I decided to get some noodle soup. Our delivery order arrived via Caviar on Friday, March 9th around 12:30pm.

I got their Pho: Your choice of beef or chicken with vietnamese rice noodle soup, scallions, white onions, and cilantro ($15.50). I'm a #1 kind of girl, so I got the beef version. The broth had a good amount of meaty flavor, but the portion was tiny. And for $15+, I would have expected at least twice the amount of noodles given. If you are actually hungry, this will leave you wanting more. Like a second bowl of pho. I did ask for extra limes, jalapenos, and hot sauce. I got the limes and hot sauce as I don't think they serve jalapenos with this dish. The hot sauce provided was a small portion, so I was glad I have a huge bottle of sriracha at my desk.

Flavor wise, I enjoyed the soup. But for the price, I would expect a bigger bowl of pho. Glad I had a side from another restaurant as I would have needed a second lunch after this. Make sure to order an app and for ask for extra noodles/meat as their pho will leave you hungry!
author: Elena N.

description: I may be biased but the pho here is a disgrace to Vietnam. The broth tasted like boiled water the noodles were super soggy and worst of all the Hoison Sauce was watered down an bland af.  Sad they took all the good food off the menu pork belly app and didn't have the two appetizers available on The menu that I ordered. Only a matter of time they go out of business. Surprised they lasted this long actually.
author: Jay H.

description:
My co worker and I come here pretty often for lunch. We love their rice bowls and the crispy rolls are amazing.

I had their angus burger yesterday and was pleasantly surprised at how amazing it was. The burger itself was seasoned perfectly. It was a little too medium for my taste. Medium here is probably a tad bit more rare so next time I'll probably ask for it well done. This bun was buttery with the right amount of crunch to it and the umami sauce was yum!!!! 

The truffle fries are never a disappointment, I just wish you got more! 

Pricing is a bit steep in my opinion. $26 including tip for a burger, fries, and drink (no refills) is a bit much. The soft drinks are very watery with very little fizz so I'd probably stick with an iced tea or sparkling water.  Service is so-so.  Once you get your food no one checks in to make sure everything is okay or to see if you want refills, napkins, etc.

Why the low stars if the food is good?  For one, service needs a little work.  If it is too busy for one person to work the floor, get some extra help.  Also, when I checked my bank account on Sunday I noticed my card was charged twice.  I reached out to Co Nam twice to get more information and to make sure the extra charge was cancelled and each time I was told the Manager would give me a call. By Wednesday, the extra charge was removed but I never received such call from the Manager, which in my opinion just shows poor customer service.

I won't be back!
author: Sabrina J.

description:
Thank you very much!  You have successfully assured I will never treat anyone how you treated me.  You have proven that you can call a customer wrong and also tell her that she no longer needs to be a customer, and it's her choice to eat there.  Thank you for the lesson and I'll make sure I never make the same mistake you did. 

I ordered the Pho Togo.  Usually it doesn't come with as many noodles in the Togo portion.  I asked for no toppings (no onion, scallion, bean sprouts,etc.) and extra noodles.  They said okay and came back saying it would be an additional $5.00 charge for the few extra noodles.  Okay, that's fine.  I'll do it because sometimes it's not enough.  

I got my soup and there were no extra noodles (or enough extra noodles for what I imagined for $5.00).  Mind you, the soup is $15.50 to start with so it ended up being $20.50 for what is pictured.  I didn't take a picture of what it usually looks like, but I did of what it looked like today.  

I called the restaurant because I believed they forgot my extra noodles, but still charged me.  The lady on the phone said, very condescendingly, "Well Dear, I did the order and added the $5.00 charge, which is our typical charge.  You didn't have to order them.  I also looked to make sure there were extra noodles so I don't know how many noodles you were expecting."  Okay, thank you, but I wasn't asking you to defend yourself or be so condescending.... and please don't call me Dear to make it seem like I'm your child.  I was telling you it didn't seem to me that the restaurant added extra noodles.  She continued and also stated it was, "your choice to eat here."  And then continued to call me, "Dear."  I asked for a manager and she said there wasn't one.

Well, no thank you and your attitude and calling me "Dear".  You can keep my $5.00, your attitude, and your noodles.  I don't need that in my life.  Hope you have a better day.  Sorry I won't be there to see if you do.
author: Angelique G.

description: The food here is pretty good, but I think there are better and more flavorful Vietnamese options within a mile or two that are much more friendly on the wallet. Co Nam is pretty standard for pho or vermicelli bowls, yet is about 5-7 bucks more for a serving than other places in the area. With that being said, the ambiance and decor is nicer here, so if you are looking for a place to impress a little more, and bring some one on a date or out for an occasion, this is a place you could check out.
author: Ross S.

description:
After a night of fun and drinking. I woke up the next morning ready for some Pho to cure me. I couldn't fathom walking to the TL for some good spots. So I settled this time around a place a bit closer to me and came across Co Nam. 

When I first entered it has a beautiful Rustic modern look to it. We were immediately sat and provided a few waters.

We started off with the shrimp spring rolls which were delicious and some Vietnamese coffee. Hoping to get the authentic slow drip at our table, more-so was coffee drinks resembling Starbucks. They were indeed good though! 

Finally on to the Pho paired with some Filet. The broth was good but the noodles were way too bundled and twisted. Overall it was alright at best.

The ambiance of this place is pleasant but due to the price point and average taste. I'd keep moving.
author: Nick F.

description: Came in last Tuesday and wasn't busy at all. Service was horrible. After 30 min I asked where our food was and they realized they forgot our order so I joked and said so we'll get this round of drinks for free? Never checked on us, we had to flag them down for water and another round. Wait over 30 more min for our food, it was ok. They brought us Brussel sprout chips we didn't order and when the bill came it was full price and only gave us the sprout chips for free, that we didn't order. Didn't tip, have never done that before, but the three of us decided it was that horrible a tip wasn't merited. Try aux delices up the street if ur on Polk and want Vietnamese
author: Angela W.

description:
I'm often asked about the best Vietnamese food in SF, well I think it's here! This is up scale Vietnamese food but in the best way. The kitchen is playful but keeps an identifiable Vietnamese flair. The ingredients are vastly superior to anything you'll find being used on Larkin Street.

The wine list is thoughtful and perfectly paid with the food. I especially loved the house beer.
author: Karen T.

description: Love this place. It's great to find a clean modern Vietnamese place with good atmosphere, nice owners and great food. The basa fish claypot and shaken beef are our faves. Also the garlic noodles are delish!  It's a great plus that they are on Uber eats as well!
author: Yasi N.

description: Hidden Treasure in Nob Hill. Co Nam delivered a great bowl of pho'. Super large portion, so now I had lunch and will have dinner. We also picked up an order of lemongrass basil chicken to go. Tired travelers, ready to spend a night in and this should do quite fine. Friendly staff and bartender Eric was great, filled with knowledge and eager to please. When in San Fran, I would highly suggest coming into Co Nam to warm up with some unique comfort food. Super cute decor and easy to find parking.
author: Tammy C.

description:
Yummy food and great atmosphere. My only qualm with this place is that I've had the same quality Vietnamese food for much cheaper, but I get that it's about the modern hip environment and the location. 

FOOD: 
- Pork belly buns: delicious! I only wish there were more of them! 
- 6 minute egg: tasty and wonderfully salty. 
- Pho with beef and beef balls: solid. Broth was very good. Really enjoyed their beef balls in particular, but it's kind of odd to have to pay extra for them here. 

Overall, great service and I would recommend this place. They have a happy hour, which I'd love to check out.
author: Emma W.

description: Super slow service, I feel bad for the worker here since she's the only one working EVERYTHING in the front. The banh mi was fairly good, however, the fries were fairly cold by the time I got them and they decided to leave a noodle on my bread. Repulsive, but, at least the bread was fairly baked and crunchy and the chicken was JUICY
author: Megan L.

description:
I came here around 2PM when no one was around. While the food is good, I was shocked at how much my vermicelli bowl was (I don't live in SF so I don't know if these prices are normal). Also I came while they were doing the airshow in SF, so I was frequently disturbed while eating my bowl as the airplane noise was very loud.

The service is excellent. I think people come here in the evening for the ambiance, but I was just looking for good food at a decent price.
author: Ellen C.

description: The food was good (not great) and wait staff was beyond obnoxious.  We either that two people waiting on us at the same time or no one could be found.  Our drinks were ordered 15 minutes before our food and still had not arrived when the food came out.  No apologies, no urgency when the food came and we told them we were expecting the drinks to go with the food and asked them to expedite.  I wanted a tiny taste of a wine sold by the glass before committing to their most expensive wine by the glass and the manager/bartender refused because the bottle wasn't open, went though they would have to open it to sell me a glass.  I was honestly tempted to abandon ship before they brought the food but honestly I was hungry enough to eat my arm so we just stayed and were pretty annoyed the entire time.  Went down the street for dessert because the idea of staying a minute longer was not fathomable.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
This place is one of my favorite restaurants in Polk. It's also probably my favorite Vietnamese restaurant in the city so far.

The place is pretty closed and not very well illuminated, but the decoration and music gives it a cozy feeling that few places in Polk have.

The food is simply amazing. No matter which noodles you're order they're going to be top notch. The bowls especially are super customizable and really good for their cost.

Since the main dish is usually enough, I haven't tried that many appetizers. Only the Beef Carpaccio and the Wicked Buns. The carpaccio was super fresh and really well accompanied. The Wicked Buns were not great, but not bad either.
author: Antonio H.

description: This is a great neighborhood spot. They usually have reservations available on Friday nights. The best things on the menu are the clay pot fish and the shakin beef.
author: Sami S.

description:
Food was ok . 
Hot Appetizers took 20min came out cold af 
Entree took over an hour but at least it was hot the cook didn't tell me they were out of Jasmine rice till my food was ready . I would of ordered something else. 
Service was horrible. I kept having to wave down the waitress 
Hire more help If you have catering job to do.


****update 
Had to wait few mins to be seated no one was in the front room. 
Wave the waitress down for tea and had to remind her after 15min-20min for my tea which wasn't that hot 
And reminded her again for our wine 
We ordered the birds nest , fried rice , and some street food 
Got there at 6:13
author: C G.

description: Went to this place based on the reviews. Food came out cold. Food is very very average for how expensive it is. Garlic noodles had a very odd taste. I don't think I would be coming back. Pretty empty on a Friday night. Much better Vietnamese food in else where in the city for half the price.
author: Michael B.

description:
It's kinda funny to see people feel frustrated to pay $20 for Thai or Vietnamese food, while they re okay for pay $30 for some other cuisines. And even though they say the food is good.
As a person who lived in 3 continents, I would say quality food needs dedication and effort. Please be open and if the food is good, pay the price regardless where it's from.
author: Darren L.

description:
Why is there cheese on the garlic noodles?!? WHY?!?!?! And it tasted more like bad chow mein than garlic noodles. 

And the pho? They messed up my order and gave me beef with chicken broth, instead of chicken with chicken broth for the pho ga. 

Not happy.
author: Fanny C.

description: Clean, nice interior with limited outside seating and more than the typical Asian beer selection. One of the best spring rolls ever. Highly recommend it.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
Pro: Love the lighting.

Con: It's quite pricey for Vietnamese food. I understand it's San Francisco, but $20 (post tax & tip) for a bowl of pho, it's lol prices lol
author: Michael H.

description: Co Nam pho not so special... the filet minon was oke... if ur really vietnamese u wouldnt love the pho here... but if ur american n try to look for something new to eat... then the pho maybe taste good to you.... the vietnamese coffee tasted funny to me.... nice restaurant though with a bar... u will see some of the viet culture while eating here.... love the service...
author: Michael P.

description: Excellent Vietnamese Food in a more high end cozy setting.  Great experience and great food!  Highly recommend!
author: Paige M.

description: Best pho I have had since moving to the city. The broth was very rich and flavorful and the chicken very tender and delicious. Also got the shrimp fresh rolls and they were excellent too. Will be ordering again soon!
author: Leslie L.

description: Waited half an hour for cold fries. The rest of the food was very very average and over priced. Would rather go to the tenderloin for good Vietnamese food instead. Customer service was also very slow unfortunately
author: Daniel Y.

description:
Food was pretty good, but service was lacking. 

I arrived with a group of 6 on Sunday at 6:30 and the place was not too busy. Initially, service was great - server came over right away for drink and app orders, and soon after came back for entrees. Apps came out quickly and were pretty good. However the entrees took an entire hour to come out. We saw several other tables receive their entrees before us. We asked a server at 45 mins where our food was and he said he'd go check. A couple minutes later, our actual server came over and apologized for the delay and said we'd get a brussel sprout tips appetizer on the house, which was a nice gesture but didn't help explain the delay. Finally we got our entrees after another 15 mins. 

Food wise it was decent, the street noodles were good (although came out lukewarm rather than hot). Prices are as you'd expect in SF for the value. Great ambiance and location, I just wish I had a better service experience here.
author: Matthew H.

description:
YELP 100 CHALLENGE 2017: 9/100.

FOURTH OF FIVE SPOTS FOR NYE! 

This is THE one spot I didn't want to miss for the night. I got the chance to take a look at these digs (via Yelp, of course) and saw way too many interesting apps I REALLY wanted to try. And since Hubbers and I were gonna be in the city anyway... HELL YES!!!

It's a small cozy place. They can probably seat just about 40 people, I'd say. Each wall has a different modern decor, pretty interesting to look at.  

Most of the tables were pretty much reserved (understood) but there were a few seats open at the bar. 

Our intention was just to have a set of drinks and maybe a couple of apps. We figure we'd be outta there in about an hour. 

But. O...M...GGGAAARRSSSHHH!!!

Other than a couple of brewskis (for me) and a few glasses of wine (for the Hubbers), we ended up ordering the following appetizers: 

BEEF CARPACCIO: This is one of the best carpaccio I've had. Presentation was nice, it was well put-together. There was an absolute Asian flair to it - slight hint of sesame oil, mint, and the crispy shallots was a nice touch. YUM! 

CHICKEN LIVER AND HEARTS: Both came with the jalapeño glaze. Both were grilled. Both were delicious. No gamey or weird after taste. 

BONE MARROW: At anytime I see roasted bone marrow on anyone's menu, I get it. This was a bit of a downer because there wasn't enough marrow for the amount of baguettes that came with it. Hardly worth the price. 

ENOKI MUSHROOMS: Who doesn't like anything bacon wrapped?! If you're a mushroom fiend, get this! Delicious! 

CRISPY PIG EAR: It really lives up to its description. They are thinly sliced, thinly battered and deep fried. Seasoning was perfect and it wasn't greasy at all. And that CRISP! It went really well with my beer! 

BEEF WRAP: Not too impressed with this one. Hubbers and I felt the beef could use a bit more seasoning. 

SHRIMP LOLLIPOP: It didn't really need the glaze. It was delicious just the way it is. But just like the bone marrow, it was also a bit of a downer - it only came with ONE. 

Hubbers and I lost track of time because we had an amazing time! 

Food. Drinks. Service. Almost perfect. 4.5 stars! 

Incroyable, Co Nam! I shall return!
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Spring rolls were so good! Love the lighting, decor, greens and ambience!
Also, great service, thanks!
author: Shivani M.

description: Food here was pretty good. The roti appetizer was super yummy. The bowls are a good portion and they are generous with the meat. I think they are a little over priced for the kind of food they offer, but nice ambiance and overall good.
author: Aya O.

description: The pho is not great pho. You don't get the rich flavor of the broth that you want in a bowl of pho. They do give a whole lot of noodles though. The wicked buns weren't that great either.. buns were cold and the meat and veggies inside weren't that flavorful either. I wouldn't come back!
author: Jeana Y.

description: We stumbled upon this restaurant and the food was fantastic!  The decor was very cool with a wall of dried moss on the back wall. The music creates a cool vibe and the service was very gracious. Their signature drink was so tasty and everyone had a great time. Highly recommend!
author: Bob S.

description: Food was amazing. The service was great. The drinks were delicious. Very pretty inside. Got to try it!
author: Alex F.

description:
I only came here for the Nem Nuong (Pork spring rolls) and hot tea, so here's my review of that:

a) The Nem Nuong was grilled and wrapped to perfection. Mouth watering, flavorful, delicious.

b) The tea did its service.

c) The service staff was friendly, the restaurant looks clean, and the atmosphere is nice.

I'm not from SF so I can't comment on its price. Overall, nice restaurant.
author: Vincent V.

description:
Ordered for delivery through UberEATS.  The delivery service is good and the foods are average.  At least we tried it but with other options in SF, no point being a repeat customer.

1. Shrimp spring rolls - you get one shrimp sliced in half with vermicelli noodles, lettuce, sprouts
2. Pork spring rolls - about the same as the other spring rolls
3. Shaken beef - c-h-e-w-y but cooked medium rare which is good 
4. Basa fish claypot - ugh, not authentic and therefore, very disappointing 
5. Wicked buns - the buns are ready made freezer kind you can get at any asian grocery, the pork belly was decent and it has a "banh mi" flavor to this appetizer
author: Kayla N.

description:
Starving and on Polk Street - not a good combo for the indecisive! What to choose? We settled on Co Nam to try something new. 
We were seated immediately. We ordered two apps: the pork belly and pork buns, both around $10. The three buns were extremely small, as in one bite small. Not exactly a bun, in my opinion. The pork belly tasted OK but it was five small and thin cut pieces. 
For the entree I ordered chicken pho. The broth was flavorful and I finished the entire bowl. For me, pho is a predictable dish to order and it met my expectations. My friends ordered clay pots, one chicken and one fish, and enjoyed them. 
Decent beer selection. I had the blueberry gimlet (OK, I had two...) and I enjoyed it. Easy to drink but it didn't taste very strong. 
The staff was very friendly and attentive!
author: Emma B.

description: We have been going to Co Nam for the past two years and their food is consistently great. Today was no exception.  We had a take out order for beef pho, seafood fried rice and spring roll. Quality of ingredients are top notched as always. You do pay more for their quality ingredients. If you are looking for cheap Vietnamese food with big portions without caring for fresh ingredients, Co Nam may not be right choice. If you are looking for quality Vietnamese food, go for Co Nam.
author: Arthur N.

description: The tastiest PHO I've ever had. No condiments on the table because it's not necessary, the food is FUL of FLAVOR. The restaurant is extremely clean with a modern design and art installations that promote cultural awareness. One can walk through the kitchen and see Vietnamese chefs prepping and preparing food with fresh ingredients.
author: M G.

description: This place is a gem. I had the delicious spicy ginger cocktail (spicy to your liking), fresh spring rolls with shrimp, make your own bowl with grilled pork, and the green papaya salad with tofu. Service was a little slow for the restaurant not being full but I would eat here again in a heartbeat.
author: Andrea S.

description:
My friends and I had a great brunch experience at Co Nam and I look forward to trying lunch/dinner here in the future. The non-traditional brunch menu really caught my eye but I was mostly excited for the $14 bottomless mimosas. 

I ordered the Egg in a Basket (a fried egg in brioche bread, served with bacon, a small salad, and potatoes) and bottomless mimosas made with grapefruit juice (they also have orange). The egg was perfectly cooked and seasoned with chives and black pepper. My friends ordered the French Omelette and French Toast, and I think they both enjoyed their dishes as well. 

For the bottomless mimosas, they give you a bottle that contains 4-5 servings of mimosas and they will bring you another bottle after you run out. 

It took a while for our food to come out, but our server was very friendly and attentive. Keep up the great work!
author: Helen P.

description: I'm a regular at this spot! Great vegetarian and vegan options as well as awesome meat options! Always have had a positive experience here. Not to mention how awesome the owner is! They also do a fantastic job catering to my food allergies.
author: Meredith P.

description: I got the vermicelli chicken bowl for lunch -- not cheap that's for sure!  (About $21 with tax). Tasty though and service was polite and quick. Like that they don't close between the traditional lunch and dinner times.
author: Tilly D.

description:
Came here with some friends. The atmosphere is very nice, great for holding conversation.

For appetizers, we shared the pork belly. A little bit on the salty side but it was cooked very well. For entrees, I had the bass fish clay pot. The fish was very well cooked. The outside was a little bit crispy and the inside was super tender. My big issue with the dish however, was that it was extremely salty. So much that it was overpowering the natural flavor of the dish. For its price, the portion sizes were on the small side but still quite filling. Overall the food was cooked well but the seasoning could use some work.
author: Cassie Z.

description:
Upscale Vietnamese restaurant with nice, modern decor. They have happy hour from 4-6pm when you can get 25% off appetizers. Service was friendly and attentive.

We ordered the shaken beef ($23) which were savory cubes of filet mignon. The texture and flavor were great. The salt and pepper sauce was super addicting. This dish wasn't enough to feed one person if you're hungry though. We also got the bun bo hue ($16) which was good. I liked the lemongrass broth and tender cuts of beef. 

Overall it's a trendier Vietnamese place so expect higher prices for smaller serving sizes.
author: Linda X.

description: Terrible experience!!!!! I have been to co nam many times and have never had a great experience. So my final time there my friend and I ordered the pho. Within a couple minutes of eating it we had both found small black hairs in our broth. When we told our waitress she acted as though this was not an issue. In the end all she did was comp one of the phos and nothing else that we had ordered! Awful customer service and establishment!
author: Talia G.

description: Excellent food! Dishes well thought out for maximum enjoyment. Stsrted off with Garlic Herb noodle that was a tasty treat with egg noodles. Basa Fish Claypot tender caramelized fish was delightful. Shaken Beef a mind altering experience with notes of taste that delivers a memorable experience. Wait staff had excellent suggestions and made our meal sensational.
author: Dwayne S.

description: Took way too long to get a pick-up order. Design of the restaurant was neat, but not worth the wait.
author: Mohamed O.

description:
Really solid Vietnamese food with good drinks to boot! The bun bo hue was surprisingly authentic and delicious, and the lemongrass chicken was so flavorful. When I came here in a weekday it wasn't really crowded so you can expect to get seated quickly. 

Overall I really enjoyed having dinner here. Yummy cocktails, good food, comfortable ambiance - what more can you ask for?
author: Claudia C.

description:
The food is ok and outside looked clean.  But I am not sure why the SFO government gave 73 points on cleanness.  Maybe something we cannot see from outside.

One thing I would like to bring to customers' attention.  This restaurant charges SF health insurance on all the orders.  SF health insurance is not a tax which passes to the consumer like sales tax.  The customers do not need and are not obligated to pay SF health insurance.  The restaurant should ask the client if he or she wants to contribute money to their employee health insurance fund first and charge it on the bill.  Without informing people and charging directly is a very dishonest way doing business.
author: Louise T.

description: This restaurant blew my mind! I wasn't well versed with Vietnamese cuisine outside of a pho, but came with a Vietnamese friend ready to try new dishes. We had a variety of dishes, all were so delicious! Shaken Beef was the best dish ever!! The meat melts in your mouth and pairs so well with the vegetables and shredded beets that are on the side. Phenomenal flavor and style in everything served. Would recommend to anyone.
author: Robby A.

description: Co nam is very underrated in my opinion. There is solid Vietnamese fusion dishes and street food options like shishito peppers and bone marrow. Their draft beer selection is strong with up to 10 different options that are quirky like the saison tsuya -- wholesome & mildly sour flavor. The interior decor is very nice with a wall of succulents and a wall of vietnam culture.
author: Young Y.

description: I used to love this place. But my most recent experience here was less than favorable. We had to wait an hour for our food. About 45 minutes in, they finally addressed us and told us it would be another 15 minutes. Finally, a minute before we were going to walk out, they brought us our food. But they didn't even get the orders right - they made the non-vegetarian version of a dish for someone who ordered the vegetarian version, and they brought us a dish that was meant to go to another table! They tried to make up for their misses by giving us the tiniest possible appetizer, which was definitely not enough for 5 people. I think the service at this place is best summarized by the words that were on the back of our waiter's t-shirt: "I'm not listening." This was the worst service I have ever experienced, and the food was not especially good either. Apparently they have a new chef, and the food is now over-salted - and they got rid of some of the best menu items! Reading some of the other reviews, this is not an uncommon experience. Unfortunately, I will no longer be a regular customer at Co Nam.
author: Megan B.

description:
This was my first time here.  The gentleman that greeted us and then was our main waiter was extremely nice.  He gave us great food and beer options to think about before we ordered.  The food had a lot of flavor.  I personally loved the street food menu and loved the claypot medley!   

The owner came by to check in on our experience which is always a nice touch.  I definitely plan on going back!
author: John C.

description: The bartender Eric was extremely amazing and quickly helped us out when we were indecisive.  I will definitely come back!!!
author: Sara P.

description:
On a cold winters night, I decided to meet a friend for a drink, but first, SOUP! Yelping the surrounding area to our bar, I came across this place and it looked super cool, so of course, I need to check it out!

The joint is super hip! The bar top was a slab of cement; obviously so were the floors. I love the wooden accents around the place. And what really caught my attention was the wall of rustic photos. It really stayed true to the theme of the "rustic Vietnamese restaurant. My servers, were awesome as well. Super personable and quick to give me recommendations. Super appreciated. 

Along with having a delicious glass of the J Lohr Pinot Noir for $12, I also got the Bun Bo Hue for $16. Wow, talk about soup brought to the 100th level! This rustic soup was filled with noodles, beef shank slices, pork sausage slices, oxtail, pigs feet and yes, blood patties. Once you get over the fact that they are pigs feet, oxtail and blood, those things are actually really good. Lots of marbleized meat so you know you're getting a bowl full of flavor. The broth was rich and delicious. I highly recommend this dish! 

If you're ever in this area, I definitely suggest coming to this joint. It's fun, hip and full of great food. You won't be disappointed!
author: Rockne H.

description:
Such a wonderful restaurant. :) Gorgeous atmosphere and a dedicated friendly staff. Our waitress tonight was a young woman from Vietnam, and she was so excited to tell us about her native food in her home country and how authentic it tastes here at Co Nam. :) She was extremely sweet and very knowledgeable, and made an impression with me and my aunt.

I almost didn't give it five stars, only because there aren't many vegan or vegetarian options that weren't essentially just vegetables.. I'm a vegetarian who hates salads, so I was struggling to find non-spicy dishes that contained tofu. With no luck, I settled for the Grilled Salmon, and it was DELICIOUS. I definitely recommend that one, although all of the dishes were objectively amazing I'm sure. Plus I hear great things about this place from others.
author: Allison D.

description: I started off with a spicy ginger cocktail which was the right mix of spice and ginger. The claypot medley came out just as I was contemplating a second drink...good thing because the beer, wine and sake selections were so robust. You will never be short on drink options here. The claypot medley was fresh, healthy and seasoned to perfection. I got in during a busy dinner rush which was a-okay because the bar was wide open and it gave me a chance to meet the owner Trong. He was as nice as the food was delicious! If you're in the city you should stop in and grab a bite. I didn't get a photo of my claypot because my cell battery died :/
author: Lyndsay M.

description: The pig ears were amazing! This protein can be difficult, but these were perfectly seasoned and crisp. The bahn mi was also very good, and the basil on the fries was a great touch.
author: Wayne G.

description: This place is awesome! They have delicious summer rolls, their papaya salad is really fresh, and they have these delicious bowls where you can mix-and-match and customize with proteins vegetables, and sauces. My only complaint is they don't stay open late enough!  It's a great spot for casual Vietnamese food.
author: Hannah C.

description:
I ordered a bunch of stuff through UberEATS here and was overall satisfied, but didn't think everything was great. 

1) Shrimp spring rolls - theses were good! With peanut sauce, and pretty standard with other shrimp rolls I've had in the past. I enjoyed these. 
2) Beef pho - this was good too! Yummy broth and soft noodles, overall good as well. Would recommend not getting beef, maybe chicken instead, when you are ordering take out because the beef comes raw and doesn't cook as well since the broth isn't as hot after the delivery. 
3) Pork bowl with vermicelli noodles - this was really good, except the pork was too salty. Otherwise it would have been perfect. 
4) Papaya salad - do not get this!! I don't understand how this was supposed to be a salad... there was no papaya, only bean sprouts and carrots with some fried tofu on top. Did not like this at all.
author: Caley Z.

description: Decided to dine in on a Sunday afternoon and was surprisingly empty. Looked at the menu and was confused as they serve different types of food as I was expecting mainly Vietnamese dishes. Ended up ordering the pho filet mignon. Was surprised by the price as it was $15. Assuming it must be some bomb pho, I gave it a try and to my surprise broth was on point. Beef was decent and noodles mixed well. Portion wise was a bit small but I can understand as it's SF. Considered the burger but I'll leave that up for next time. Nice cozy interior, which I always put into consideration when dining out.
author: Dave N.

description:
I should have known before we were seated that this place may not have been what I was looking for. I was hoping for some amazing, traditional Vietnamese food with a twist of farm-to-table options & fresh flavors.

We opted for some street food skewers which were okay. The waiter took our order wrong, so we didn't get what we wanted. By the time we figured it out... it was too late to ask for a correction.

I ordered the Bun Bo Hue, and the flavor wasn't bad. It wasn't spicy at all but the flavor was enough to make up for it.  I was appalled at how big the slices of meat were. They were cut like how my blind grandmother would slice them at home.  I wouldn't mind the slices being so thick and large, IF the meat was tender enough to bite through. I felt like I was playing tug-of-war with a beef tongue.  Also, they only provided one small piece of the pig's ankle, which is a staple for the dish.  I was also appalled that they charged as much as they did for this bowl of tough meat and didn't even offer the banana blossoms that are also a must.  Please don't say you can't find it, because if I could find them in Portland, I can definitely find them in SF.  And hold the door...white cabbage? Are you that gentrified that you couldn't even opt for the purple cabbage? 

My husband ordered the burger and couldn't bite through the meat.  Don't get me started on that monstrosity.  

Note: If you want Vietnamese food, don't go here. If you want a combination of stuff on pretty plates, go here.
author: Julie L.

description: Good beer list and decent menu but the service was slow, the food took more than an hour to arrive, and the manager was unbelievably rude.  Should be a great place but with this approach to service it is not worth a visit...
author: Daniel H.

description: This restaurant's staff and manager named Erik were extraordinarily rude to us and the service was remarkably slow. We placed entree orders around 7:30pm and the food didn't arrive until 8:30. We told them we had to get back to our babysitter and didn't have a ton of time. When we asked if it was normal for service to take over an hour they said yes, that was normal. I asked Erik if he could apologize for the slow service and consider comping anything and he called me "crazy" and told me to pay the full bill and leave his restaurant as soon as possible. I have never been this insulted in a restaurant and I would strongly recommend against eating here.
author: Josie H.

description: This restaurant used to be a neighborhood gem, however the last few times I have eaten there have been utterly disappointing. They served dishes without key ingredients (ie tofu), claimed a dish was vegan when it had fish sauce and took 30 mins to prepare one take out dish that was returned since they provided us an incomplete dish (noodles without sauce or tofu, just boiled vegetables). Sadly, due to multiple bad experiences, I will no longer be a customer at Co Nam.
author: Ketki K.

description: They got my order wrong... so I asked them if I could have the extra dish while they made the one I actually ordered. They didn't give it to me. And I waited a long time. But then... the waitress came back later and asked me if I wanted to order another dish, on the house. So I ordered the stone fish clay pot and it was good. I ate a lot that night and I was satisfied. I would definitely return despite the small hiccup at the start-it was very worth it. Thanks!
author: David T.

description: Polk street has both changed and remained the same since we left the area in 2002: Cool bars and eateries but still grungy and on-the-edge. Picked this place after some music at Mayes Oyster House and was pleasantly surprised. Great flavors in all 3 of our dishes: The bacon wrapped enoki mushrooms - great idea!; The beef lemongrass dish was so fresh and tasty, not soupy at all, wow!; And the combination dish had more protein than other filler stuff, all bathed in a lovely sauce that didn't disappoint. Hoi Polloi beer on tap from our Oakland neighborhood was an extra treat and we finished the meal with fried banana wrapped in a wonton. Very impressed with Co Nam!
author: Chris L.

description:
The service is the reason why this review isn't 4 stars! The lack of attention, the forgetfulness of orders (drinks) and slowness of the kitchen made it just too distracting to fully enjoy our meal! You should not have to work that hard for food and drink during a Sunday brunch. We weren't the only customers who noticed, incorrect food was delivered to our table as well as the two tables on either side of us. Servers not using their table numbers!!

Other than that, the ambiance is quite nice with a good mix of natural wood, gray walls and greenery. Our vermicelli bowls had great flavor on the meat, fresh and crispy vegetables and the right amount of side sweet sauce it for a bit more depth.
author: Megan C.

description:
So delicious, I woke up the next day regretting I did not take my leftovers home. 

I had the fish hot pot with a side of jasmine rice. The sauce was so yummy and the fish was perfectly cooked. 

Also I suggest trying a cocktail. I had the Elderflower cocktail which was light, floral and refreshing.
author: Angie K.

description: Absolutely fantastic food and excellent service. We tried several appetizers along with a speciality beer and cucumber martini and everything was fantastic. Highly recommend the roti and grilled shishito peppers along with the garlic noodles. The calamari salad and shrimp spring rolls were also great. Can't wait to come back!
author: Audrey K.

description:
I passed by this place a few times and wanted to check it out. I was a little skeptical at first because it looks very fancy and Americanized. The decor and the pictures on the wall was what caught my eye in the first place. I love it. 

I came here for brunch and bottomless mimosas on a Sunday. The service was great. The waitress and the bartender where super nice. 

Instead of getting the traditional American brunch, we got the Vietnamese noodle bowls. It was very good! I can't go to a Vietnamese restaurant and order American food. We also got the beignets for dessert. The waitress told us the sauce for the beignet is condensed milk and peanut butter. 

The whole experience was great. 
I definitely recommend this place if you are in the neighborhood.
author: Edie G.

description:
Totally overpriced.

$29.32 for lunch for:

spring rolls

chicken clay pot

was over cooked very chewy

I have never written a poor review of restaurant on yelp before
author: John S.

description: Got the Bottomless mimosa, beignets, shishito peppers, grilled pork rice bowl and the tofu vermicelli noodles. Everything was delicious. Good service and I like the modern casual ambiance. I recommend this place
author: Ro N.

description:
This is one of the best Vietnamese restaurants I've been to! I ordered the pork rice bowl and it reminded me of my mom's cooking. It's authentic, delicious, and will leave you full and happy as their portions are very generous. It's a little on the pricey side, but I think it's worth it! 

The veggies were fresh and the pork was seasoned perfectly. Even though they gave fish sauce on the side to drizzle on top of your food, it wasn't necessary! Most Vietnamese restaurants I go to make the meat so dry and bland that you need the sauce. This restaurant did an excellent job in seasoning their pork perfectly!

On top of that, drinks and HH deals are great! My mojito was pretty strong and the lychee drink will leave you with a buzz.

It's a very cute restaurant and perfect for those who love Vietnamese food or for those who have a big appetite!
author: Jenny L.

description: This was a cute spot. Came here with some friends who are locals. Salad calomri was bomb. Recommended if you wanna do bottomless mimosas. Vibes are great, food is great, staff is kind. Totally come here if you want to chill.
author: Frank R.

description: Food was weird and wayyy too much pepper. Drinks were fine.
author: Michelle T.

description:
We tried grabbing dinner & drinks at Amelie across the street and ending up being seating in a table in front of another couple, super awkward and had to yell since it was so loud so we walked down Polk and found Co Nam. Co Nam sits in a nicer part of Polk street than what I am generally used to and has a nice, trendy interior. It's a great place for a quiet dinner date. We didn't make any reservations ahead of time but luckily, there was no wait on a Friday night around 7pm and we were seated right away. 

We had ordered the wicked buns and I personally feel like they lacked flavor, even having put sriracha sauce on. I would say my only recommendation would be the shaken beef!This was absolutely delicious, and juicy with an order of a side of jasmine rice.
author: Karen C.

description: This is our go-to Vietnamese restaurant, and a great option for both last-minute dinners out and special meals.  The pho is the best I've ever had. If you're treating yourself, have the shaking beef.  It's actually a wonderful value at $24 conserving they use filet mignon and oh yeah yum yum yum. You really can't go wrong here. Get the roti from the street foods menu to start. It's just a bite or two but so flaky and good maybe get two. It comes with a delicious curry dipping sauce. If I'm doing a healthy meal out, I get a salad bowl which is like a rice bowl or noodle bowl but low carb and very satisfying! Beer and wine options are an excellent value but excellent quality. We are always amazed this place isn't more packed considering the beautiful decor, good lighting, friendly service, and top notch food. Don't tell too many friends!
author: Tom M.

description: It took 2 hours to get our food. When it came out the birds nest dish we ordered was cold and tasted bland. We think it was under sauced, but we didn't care at that point. Only come here if you're up for cold food and waiting 2 hours for your food to come.
author: Will H.

description: Vin and Am are the best chefs ever. I got a chance to meet them and showed me their process of how they make they're food and their A1. Mimosas automatically getting refilled is a nice touch as well. I recommend this classy place to everyone.
author: Logan M.

description:
Sorry, the most weirdist review ever... So I'm sitting with some friends eating dinner at this Vietnamese place (At least I thought it was Vietnamese based on it's name and description) But after eating the food I guess I'm not sure.

Anyhow, there's this guy at the bar that just starts coughing and wheezing and I'm like OMG, he's having a heart attack or something.

Suddenly some guy comes out from the back wearing a t-shirt and goes behind the bar and starts talking to the bar guy (customer).

It sounds like he said he was the owner and asked what the problem was.

The bar guy said he had an allergy (It looked like he was being poisoned), and told the owner guy that he must list ingredients on the menu so people with allergies could be safe. He even pointed to other entries where the proper ingredients were listed.

Here is where it get weird....

The Owner guy basically tells the customer guy to FUCK OFF!!! and I'm like OMG, WTF??
He tells the customer guy that he owns this place and he can do what he wants!!!

The owner guy then tells the customer to pay his bill and leave.

WTF???  I've never in my life seen an owner of a business Fuck over a customer in their establishment!!

The guy paid and left, but I don't know if he had to go to hospital or what. Also, we just got sick after that so we paid and left as well.

I can NEVER, EVER go back to that place again with such a SHIT owner and so Disgraceful!!!!

I'm sick to my stomach right now as I write this.
author: mary p.

description:
I really dig Co Nam. I've been more than a couple times now, so it's time for a proper review. The takeaway is that their food is absolutely delicious: fresh, healthy, tasty and simply well prepared. I like both the meat dishes and the noodle/rice bowls (I always sub for brown rice - it's delicious). Lots of great options for vegetarian or meat/seafood sides too. 

Bonus: the brussels chips side is DELICIOUS. I believe each leaf is peeled off then baked, sinful.

My only gripe is that the service is spotty pretty consistently. They're very friendly and helpful with the menu, but it often seems like they're one server short. Either something doesn't make it to the table, or an order is off, or takes forever to get a water refill. Things like that. Not lazy service, just in-the-weeds. This will never stop me from going here, because Co Nam is great, but I think they can do a wee bit of work on their table service.
author: Meredith R.

description:
This is my go-to-joynt every Saturday for lunch, and if your in the area you should too! The draft beers selection is among the best. La Fin du Monde, Monk's Cafe, Allagash Curieux....shall I keep going..these are craft beers, among the best. They also have an amazing bloody mary that will make you wanting another. They wine selections, red and white awesome. I've even see several sake brands that are also premium.

The app menu is wicked, hearts, liver, squid, mushrooms, all prepared in a tasty flamed method. The breakfast, I know is great because I can hear everyone talking, eating and laughing it up. I absolutely love their noodle bowls. It comes with either chicken, beef or pork. It is so yummy, and addicting and delicious that you'll be craving it soon enough.

The service and servers are wonderfully kind, knowledgeable and super approachable. They personally cater to each and every guest regardless of age, gender or drunkness (kidding about the last one). I always feel so VIP when I drop in every Saturdays. I'm gonna keep going back because I love the vibes, people and especially the food and draft beers!
author: Suprkwn K.

description: Last night was my first time at Co Nam. The food portions were very small, but delicious! We really loved the seafood fried rice. The lollipop shrimp came with an amazing sauce that the waitress informed us was made of cashews. I would definitely go back here again!
author: Zinia G.

description:
Went there on a rainy Sunday at 2pm, expecting it to be empty -- but it was full! Small, narrow space with seating for about 30 maybe. Long bar as well. Pretty noisy from the music, but as it turns out, we were sitting right underneath the speaker. 
Food was great! We both got the bun -- known as "noodle bowls" here. I got mine with 5 spice chicken, my friend got it with lemongrass beef. All the usual accoutrements -- greens, sprouts, carrot, daikon, nuoc nam. Tasty and large bowls -- I couldn't finish mine. If you're looking for middle priced VN food, this is definitely a place to try!
author: Yasi S.

description:
Update.  Came here  a couple of more times after and it has improved (or maybe grew on me).  Food was tasty and service was friendly.  I recommend getting the steak carpaccio (super yum) and the claypot fish dish.

Good low key spot on Polk for date nights.  =)  

Also, Henry at the bar is super friendly and the service was great.
author: Vicky T.

description: Loved it. Great little spot. Good ambiance. Friendly service. Delicious and innovative food. I'll be back soon.
author: Mark S.

description: It's pretty okay but I've had better. A lot of 5 spice in their pho and the papaya salad was super bland. Crispy rolls were pretty good.
author: Irina M.

description: A meh and expensive bowl of pho. Came here after doing an escape room in the area because we were cold and hungry, the interior is nice but the food was only ok. We got much more excited buying and eating fresh Bob's Donuts next door.
author: Wen L.

description: We started with the crispy rolls. They were warm, moist, mildly spiced and soft inside. Just perfect. Then we moved to the salad, combo seafood for me and the bird's nest as the delicious main dish. The ambiance combines dim lights with soft music and a beautiful modern decor.
author: Renata V.

description:
I stumbled upon Co Nam close to when it first opened and have been going ever since - the combination of great food, quick service, well designed drinks and good people is sometimes hard to find, and this little authentic vietnamese restaurant has figured it out.

The Drinks:
They have a great assortment of cocktails, beer, wine and sakes including one of my personal favorites - Hitachino Nest.

The Food:
I have never had anything but great food here which is always plated nicely.
In particular I recommend the Basa Fish Claypot, the variety of rolls they make and the pho.

The Ambiance:
Trung and his staff are friendly, fast and committed to a great experience
The restaurant is usually quiet enough to have a conversation
You can't beat the living wall and soft lightning for overall feel

So in short if you find yourself looking for fresh original vietnamese, a great drink and a cool place to enjoy it I highly reccomend Co Nam.
author: Mirja T.

description: So yummy! Quality ingredients, each dish seems simply but full of flavor. No huge line on a Fri night, seated right away. We ordered wicked buns, crispy egg rolls, calamari skewer, veggie skewer, shrimp lollipops and beef pho. The street food skewers and lollipops were a little expensive ($4 for one lollipop ball!?) and if you're not used to paying double digits for a bowl of pho, be warned it's $14. It was definitely one of the 'cleanest' and much higher quality beef you'd get compared to any other pho joint. Overall, the dishes were delicious, great vibe and great service. We'll definitely be back to try more dishes.
author: Angela L.

description:
I was in SF for the weekend, so I'm not sure if I caught this place on a bad night... I really wanted to like it, but I've experienced better.

Service:
The service was friendly, but painfully slow. We had to ask for water. We had to ask for refills. We had to ask about our food.We had to ask for our check... twice! It felt like we had to check-in on the status of everything. In short, the service was friendly, but not attentive or proactive.

Food:
They have a full menu and then a "street food" menu that they recommended for quicker eats. To start I ordered the "shishito peppers" but found out they were all out. The server recommended we try the veggies, so we got that. When they came out my first reaction was "is this it?" to which the server said yes. I wish I took a picture because it was the saddest display of veggies ever. Imagine having 2 green beans cut into a few pieces and then maybe 1 piece of asparagus. Then it was placed on a skewer. It tasted amazing... which I'll give them, but the portion was TERRIBLE for a price of around $4 for the item. If they revamped the menu to lower the price OR increase the portion this would be better. The taste was awesome, but you don't get a good value in portion size.

For my entree I opted to get a vermicelli bowl with pork and added the fried egg and egg roll. I was a little surprised that the fried egg and egg roll didn't come with the bowl, especially since the price of the bowl was around $16 -- the egg roll and fried egg were about $2 extra (each). The pork was seasoned really well and tasty, but overall I thought the bowl lacked enough lettuce. The presentation was nice, but for the price I think they should include an egg roll and fried egg with the meal.


Drinks:
I didn't order any cocktails, but did have to ask for water, and our first two refills. I also ordered a coke, but didn't realize refills weren't free. I'm not sure if they're using a mexican coke, but the glass is super small. The server was very nice and let me know that normally refills were charged the full price of another drink, but since I didn't know he wouldn't charge me for the 2nd one. I appreciated this... but think if they're going to charge for each glass they should just bring the bottle/can to you so you know you're getting the entire thing. I don't feel like the glass they gave me was a full 12 oz beverage.


Overall I wouldn't recommend this place (off of this first time visit), nor would I return here. I kept wanting to like the restaurant, but felt like they were failing big time... and it wasn't even packed! Since I was out of town visiting, I'm not sure if this was just an off night, which every place can have, or if this was their typical routine. Some of the flavors in their food were awesome, so I don't think the food is the problem... but they should definitely work on ironing out the other kinks.
author: Ishea B.

description:
Cute place. It's a small place, but well-run. Great décor.

1. Thai iced tea: Standard, which is good.

2. Bird's nest: I enjoyed the fresh veggies, mushrooms, and the sunny-side up egg on top of crispy noodles. Well-flavored without being overpowering.

3. Wicked buns: Pork belly in bready buns. This is a classic Taiwanese dish, actually, and it did not disappoint. You get 3 pieces per order. I just wished there were more since they were so delicious.

4. Bass claypot: The fish was very tender and flavorful. Satisfying! 

Overall, I liked everything I had here. It's definitely reasonably priced especially for this neighborhood.
author: James W.

description: Decent place to get some Vietnamese food. We had the veggie rolls which were alright, and different kinds of rice bowls. The portions were pretty big and tasty, we were satisfied in general, would gladly come back if we happen to be in the neighborhood but probably not make a big trip just for this.
author: Ioannis K.

description:
After walking from the Castro to Fort Mason, my friends and I wanted something light and had vegetarian options. We unanimously decided on Vietnamese and out came the various review apps. Simultaneously we decided on Co Nam (which was also still a hike away, and with many intriguing spots, but we were dead set).

We arrive a little after one and the place is dead, but the staff was incredibly friendly and helpful, pointing out that while they were still in brunch mode (served until 3, and offers bottomless mimosas), lunch was an option as well.

Both menus were very impressive and a group could go with small plates and get a lot of variety (pork crispy rolls, shrimp crispy rolls, shrimp fresh rolls, etc.). And with all the variety - we all got noodle and rice bowls.

For what it is worth, I really enjoyed the pork belly rice bowl. The pork belly was incredibly tender, easy to break into smaller pieces with chopsticks, but YOU MUST pour that pork belly sauce on it. Wow, was that full of flavor (and most likely delicious fat). And you can add a crispy roll ($2) or an egg ($1), which isn't too bad and well worth it.

Retouching on variety is the drink menu. While they had an impressive tap and bottle selection for beers (including some of the less common Asian beers), after all the walking a beer didn't sound all that great. But a mojito did, and they had a selection of those as well. Had to go with the passion fruit and it was worth it (although the bar tender mentioned he wasn't the normal bar tender, he did an excellent job). My friends also enjoyed their bowls - the vegetarian got the brussel sprout chips for his and said they made the bowl even better.

Also worth mentioning: the living wall behind the bar, the great views you get when walking past the kitchen to the restroom (I wanted to grab the pork belly, it was right there) and the sweet faucet in the bathroom. Hey, sometimes things catch your eye.

I would like to return here for either a more traditional brunch or dinner.
author: Michael C.

description: My girlfriend and I were looking for a brunch place and stubbed upon this gem. The "$13 bottomless mimosas" sign really caught our eyes, so the excellent food was just icing on the cake. There was no one inside which worried us but we still followed through and got a table for two. All of the food was very tasty, sauces included, which were (no judging, we were hungry) shisito peppers, shrimp roll, 2 orders of bottomless mimosas, roti, shrimp lollipops (most delish thing I had!), and beef pho. Everything was great and our waitress Kiran was so sweet! The new guy (I'm assuming) claimed that we could only have raspberry mimosas since that was the first one we ordered but she came up and asked if we wanted raspberry, orange or grapefruit, grapefruit being the best. Lastly, Right before the time ran out for bottomless mimosas, she came up and informed us that it was ending and I, being slight buzzed at this point, mentioned for her to surprise us with the flavor of our last carafe, which she made a mango mimosa! Everything was great, including the throw back jams. Def coming back!
author: Johnny L.

description: Only dropped in for a quick lunch. Haven't been a huge fan of Vietnamese cuisine since a trip to Vietnam a number of years back. After only having the Pho this time, I am more than excited to return and sample more from the menu, especially the street food. Good food & service in a modern setting. Good work Co Nam. Lastly, the menu is very accommodating to anyone avoiding gluten for any of many reasons.
author: Rob L.

description:
3.5 STARS for food.
4.5 STARS for service.

Co Nam is a cute little upscale Vietnamese restaurant on Polk St in Russian Hill. Having read the fairly harsh reviews from my fellow Yelpers I was quite concerned I had booked a reservation on Opentable. There were highlights and lowlights but from an upscale Vietnamese restaurant perspective I thought it was tasty.

* BRAISED PORK BELLY ($ 8) - 4 STARS:
Served with a cashew nut garnish. It was tender, fatty and flavorful - I just wish there was more.

* CRISPY SPRING ROLLS ($ 8) - 3.5 STARS: 
Chicken, shrimp, wood-ear mushroom, glass noodle, carrot, jicama, nuoc cham. I'm not sure I tasted any of the ingredients listed, but I did notice that the spring roll was fresh out of the fryer, perfectly crispy and piping hot. This was a great way to start the meal.

* BEEF CARPACCIO ($ 14) - 2 STARS:
Filet mignon, rau ram, mint, crispy shallot, red onion, cashew, nuoc cham. The preparation from the menu description sounded on point, but unfortunately the odd text of the extra thick cut raw beef was not appetizing to me. The extra ingredients were not enough to counteract the feeling that I was biting straight into a live cow. Not my cup of tea.

* BASA FISH CLAYPOT ($14) - 4 STARS:
Braised basa fish, carmelized with black pepper, Thai bird chili and scallion. Basa is a hearty white fish which stands up well against the very flavorful, slightly sweet and thickened Thai/Viet style sauce. I liked that it was hearty, yet not dry. They have a version with chicken.

* SHAKEN BEEF ($21) - 4 STARS:
Filet mignon cubes, green onions, sauteed in garlic pepper sauce, organic baby watercress, lemongrass viniagrette, salt and pepper lime dipping sauce. Super tender, flavorful but a bit on the expensive side. I'm happy with Bodega Bistro's which is just as good and cheaper.

I'm generally not one to gravitate towards the upscale Vietnamese restaurants since they are on the expensive side and don't always serve something unique or worthwhile. I still love Tin for their Bun Bo Hue and Pho, and Slanted Door for their crab vermicelli, but I really enjoyed Co Nam for the Basa Claypot. Can't wait to return for brunch or happy hour!
author: Jess C.

description: I was on my own, so I didn't get to try many dishes, but my dinner was excellent! Flavors spot on, ingredients much better than average, and lovely to be able to get a decent glass of wine. I will definitely go back!
author: Lisa R.

description: The wings comes in 5 pieces. It's also very salty. I wrote this review the day I had my first experience there but unfortunately yelp had my first review taken down. This is my experience, costumer service was not so friendly, maybe the restaurant had a bad day, but don't take it out on me. It took a server a while to notice me as I tried to figure out if I should just sit anywhere or wait for a server. Second, I reviewed that the wings are the best. My opinion, it was too salty and the price I paid for was not worth it. Overall, I rated this place 3 stars. I've ordered take out before but this was my first experience dining in. I also had the spicy bun bo hue. I'm very particular about my bun bo hue, I also rate this dish a 3 as well.
author: Lily Ann L.

description:
Q: Whats a Vietnamese coffee?

Best fancy Banh Mi ever

Co Nam's tagline is "rustic Vietnamese" and while the venue is well designed inside and out - there's very little "rustic" about it.  Its a lot more gourmet fusion than rustic. As Anna noted any place that calls itself rustic - almost definitely wont be.

Co Nam's banh mi is the best i've ever had.  Its almost to banh me what Giordanos Bros is to "sandwiches" yeah its technically a Vietnamese sandwich but thats an understatement.

We also split an order of beignets - which comes with Vietnamese coffee if you can appreciate good sweet coffee you should give Co Nam's a try.

Other items looked equally well crafted and the presentation alone provided a reason to return.


A: its a drip coffee that comes with your GLASS (as in not cup) and slowly fills it up over some condensed milk.
author: Oleg H.

description: Delicious Vietnamese cuisines in a chic modern restaurant. Their menu doesn't come as too extensive of a list but I had trouble choosing because everything sounded great. Plus they have a great selection of alcohol. I had the lemongrass chicken with rice and it came out perfect. The chicken was marinated well and was so tender. I loved everything from the modern twist on traditional Viet decorations to the bold flavors of the food. I will be stopping by here again when I'm in SF.
author: Evana L.

description: Co Nam is so incredibly delicious. As someone else mentioned, I think this place is totally underrated. They consistently serve up fresh, unique and inspired takes on Vietnamese food. Their 'street food' menu is full of interesting choices and their pork chop brined and then marinated in sweetened condensed milk and 'umami sauce' is literally the best pork chop I've ever had. This place is serving the best Vietnamese food in SF right now.
author: Kira M.

description:
Come here for the:
Friendly staff
Fresh ingredients
Delicious food
Diverse menu
Trendy decor

Brace yourself for:
Loud music
Sweeeet thai tea (objective and may differ another day)
Smaller portions (not your local Viet hole in the wall)

We ordered:
Basa Claypot (fish only) $14
Rice $2.50
Papaya Salad $10
Mango Sticky Rice $7
Thai Tea $0 (yelp check in)

All were delicious!
author: Michelle C.

description: The best thing we got was the burger.. so that says something about this Vietnamese restaurant.  The service was pretty good, and the space was fine as well, but the food is bad (well.. other than the burger of course). Ultimately, we wont be coming back since there are better and cheaper burgers out there in the world.
author: John S.

description: Vietnamese food served in a nice restaurant /ambiance means you're not paying cheap Chinatown prices for authentic Viet food. Dining here means you're paying a small fortune for smaller portions of their Americanized counterparts.  Don't get me wrong, the food is decent. In fact, it tastes really good. But it's not worth it for the price or portion. You might leave here hungry after paying $50 for dinner, like I did for the shaken beef cubes + a bowl of rice because it doesn't come with the entree + a drink.
author: Emily C.

description: Had a delicious meal at Co Nam. The service was super attentive. The entrees were well balanced, not too sweet. My friend had a really nice ginger cocktail. I really liked the lemongrass chicken, very succulent. Plus a very nice decor. Would definitely return.
author: Stacey S.

description:
I wanted to love this place so much. It's a cute, hip little Vietnamese restaurant with an awesome menu. The staff is great and the food was tasty. But every meat item I was served was undercooked. I ordered the chicken heart and chicken liver skewers, and the calamari salad. The calamari was so undercooked it was still a little translucent. My chicken heart literally dropped blood on to my white plate. And the liver was definitely also undercooked. 
I should probably give only 1 star, considering I got food poisoning and am not in the greatest shape currently. (Hoping the pepto-bismol kicks in soon.) However, it's my fault for not sending the food back. The waitress mentioned to me the cooks say "that's the way they grill their calamari," so I took her word and assumed it was safe to eat. I should have been smarter about the chicken!!
author: Amy C.

description:
You can tell a lot about a restaurant from the restroom sink. Yes, that's true. Don't roll your eyes at me. And there's quite a sink in the men's room. It's a huge stone rectangle with multiple layers in the basin. Bold shades of blue, green and teal on each layer (photo: http://bit.ly/1b8cX29). I remember washing my hands thinking maybe it's meant to evoke the rice terraces in North Vietnam since the painting on the back wall picks up the same patterns. Or maybe there was a sale on really ugly sinks at Home Depot. But that's the kind of design decision that informs this hipster-heavy Vietnamese spot on Polk. It's not that far from Little Saigon, but it might as well be in another dimension for all it has to do with those family-run places.

No, Co Nam is brought to you from owner Kiet Truong who owns Unicorn (pretty good - my review: http://bit.ly/1e4VBEu) and Region (pretty dismal - my review: http://bit.ly/1g3eCDU). Co Nam is somewhere in between food-wise but definitely in the same family as the other two when it comes to slightly overdone, swank decor. I mean, just look at that sink.  The menu is described as rustic Vietnamese (photo: http://bit.ly/1g3e68Z), but I'm not sure what that means when everything is so impeccably presented on small plates. I decided to try two appetizers instead of an entree just to experience more culinary variety. First up was the $8 Garlic Herb Noodle which was stir-fried in Parmesan cheese and fried shallots (photo: http://bit.ly/18WkKtM). It was no match for Perilla, something tells me the Parmesan cheese is not an authentic touch.

My second dish was the $8 Braised Pork Belly with Cashew Nut Garnish (photo: http://bit.ly/1g3dMHb). You don't have to twist my arm to eat pork belly, but five slices seemed a bit on the skimpy side, and frankly the ground cashews were an unnecessary touch. I made room for dessert, and the $7 Mango Sticky Rice was topped with chopped fresh mango and cashews and accompanied by a shot of coconut creme (photo: http://bit.ly/1b8dlOd). I liked it, but there wasn't nearly enough of it to satisfy, so I completed the meal with a soothing $7 pot of the Dragon Pearl Jasmine Tea (photo: http://bit.ly/14HuNHh). That did the trick. The service, by the way, was quite attentive without being intrusive. Maybe another visit would make me swoon over the place, or maybe I'll just hang out in the men's room.

FOOD - 3 stars...middling Vietnamese fare targeted to a hipper crowd
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...that sink!
SERVICE - 4 stars...here is where they excel
TOTAL - 3 stars...but the food does not

P.S...Subsequent to my review, the current owner pointed out to me that Co Nam is under new management and no longer associated with Kiet Truong.
author: Ed U.

description:
Last month I went to Co Nam for dinner in celebration of a co-worker's birthday. When I first found out where we were going, I looked it up on Yelp and noticed it was a trendier, cute, Vietnamese restaurant. What?! I'm used to my traditional, hole in the wall, casual, bright Vietnamese restaurants. 

When I arrived at Co Nam, I noticed how small it was. It had a fun vibe going on and it was cozy. We arrived early for our reservation and hung out at the bar - drinks and service were great. After being seated, service was great throughout the rest of the meal. Their food was delicious - we ordered a variety of items, however, I LOVED their basa fish claypot and shaking beef. 

I would definitely return and am already thinking of when my next visit will be.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
The Shaking Beef here convinced me to never be boring and only get pho/spring rolls from vietnamese restaurants again.

Food:
-Shaking beef, aka vietnamese-style filet mignon cubes, magically marinated and tender, basically life changing.
-Basil lemongrass chicken, the chicken had perfectly infused lemongrass and basil flavors with a side of subtly savory jasmine rice, tasted like culinary mad skills
-Basa fish claypot, decent but on the more predictable side and didn't stand out  
-Sugarcane shrimp spring rolls, nothing too unique for $10

Very friendly service, typical SF claustrophobic dining space. Still dreaming of those jizzworthy beef cubes.
author: Tian Q.

description:
I've been here for 4 times!! Co nam burger is amazing and Delicious!Pattaya salad is fresh ,highly comment to come
Here with friends!
author: Keke C.

description:
A colleague and I had dinner there the other night, and we both were very happy! The food was excellent, with each dish having very distinctive flavors, nothing over-powering other dishes. We had a combo of what they call "Street Food", which is basically small bites/tapas, papaya salad and entrees. The street food we had included shrimp lollipop (very flavorful), enoki mushroom wrapped in bacon (yummy) and roti (a bit greasy, not the best I've had). The entrees we had included shaking beef (very tender and juicy) and lemongrass chicken (very flavorful), the latter of which was served on a bed of white rice. 

The portions are on the small side for everything, except for the lemongrass chicken entree, which was why the two of us had to order so much food to feel satisfied. Each shrimp lollipop was one ball, so we had to double the order for each, i.e., 4 total. The bill came to just under $90 for the two of us without drinks, so definitely not a cheap eat. However, there are cheaper menu options, if you want to spend less than we did. Our server was very attentive, filling our water glasses very frequently, and another staff member promptly took care of an error on the bill. We liked the ambience a lot, too. It wasn't overly noisy, so we could talk. The restaurant has a trendy but intimate feel for visiting with friends (or even a date) over good food.
