With all that said, definitely recommend Co Nam and will definitely go back the next time I'm in Nob Hill.
author: Alice C.

description: The service is ok, but Not the right place for pho. I ordered one beef pho, and found that the basil and sprouts were not fresh. The beef tastes a little bit wired. And the soup was the sweetest I've ever had for a pho. Note: the chili pepper is very hot. And it is pricy.
author: Xuejun L.

description: We randomly stopped in with a group of five. They were super efficient and fast in their service and getting us our orders. We ordered the calamari, steam buns, and vermicelli. All of it was pretty good. It was definitely some of the best vermicelli I've had in a while.
author: Jen H.

description:
My homegirl and I literally spent all day snoopin around trying to a spot to eat for dinner. We both decided we wanted pho, so we decided Vietnamese. We then decided vermicelli, only after looking at the menu for Co Nam. We looked at the pictures on yelp and decided this was gonna be our spot for the evening.

We called in for reservations at 7 and somehow mysteriously they weren't taken in their computer system. Had they been super slammed and busy this might've caused a predicament. Thank lord baby jesus they were a bit slower this evening because we got sat right next to this wall of moss. I'm a huge fan of plants/animals/earth so once I noticed it I got pretty distracted. On top of this I thought the bar looked incredibly fucking cool, like reminded me of something underground; very low key. Originally when we sat the lights were noticeably bright, I think the owner cruised in and turned them down a bit. That's where things started being really awesome.

Our waiter (forgot if he mentioned his name), was super informed about the menu. Talked us into getting appetisers when we normally don't ever do. This included some pork spring rolls and some Vietnamese street food. Holy fucking shit the spring rolls were fantastic. They were incredibly fresh tasting and balanced with this dipping sauce that was equally fantastic. The street food was several meats and some green onions skewered and cooked up. Pork, chicken heart, something wrapped in bacon, and green onions. Another fantastic treat.

Both my homegirl and I decided upon vermicelli bowls. She got the chicken. I got the BBQ pork. Neither of us made the wiser decision as they both absolutely tremendous. Super flavorful, and incredibly fresh tasting ingredients. It looked as good as it tasted, so much so the table next to us saw what we were eating, asked what it was, and ordered the exact same thing.

We also ordered some cocktails while there, the spicy ginger one, the mojito, and I forgot the other two now. I think I got one that was elderberry. A different waiter said the top three drinks on the menu were the most OG drinks on the menu. The cocktails were pretty good, but something is always lost in translation across the use of sake/soju instead of classic liquors.

This was probably the best dining experience I've had since living in the city. I hesitate to say you'll find a better experience nearby, if at all.
author: Jim B.

description: Food took 45 minutes to come out. Portions not large or particularly tasty. Prices are high. Service was not friendly. It's a shame because the restaurant is really nice looking inside.
author: Elliott S.

description:
Service was a little slow and kind of all over the place but the food did make up for it. 

It took a long a time to get out drinks and appetizers and then when they finally did, they brought the entrees with it too so we had to eat it all together. They also forgot to bring one of our sides, but at that point, it was kind of a mute point. 

Re. the food, then that's a different business. The pig ears were strong and the cid was amazing! Definitely recommend the spinach ginger drink.
author: Guilherme B.

description:
Food was not that great. 
Atmosphere is nice.
Somewhat expensive.
author: Nitesh D.

description: The pho was amazing!  It reminded me of the pho I had for breakfast every morning in Vietnam.  They give you Thai chilies on the side instead of jalapeño, it added intense heat.  I could eat a bowl of this pho every day, craving it just thinking about it.  Decent wine too, great ambiance and great service. Highly recommend.
author: Cari N.

description:
Early dinner here on Saturday night. We made reservations but didn't really need to as we were the first table there. Nice airy space and a bar section. Service was really friendly and gracious right off the bat. The host was great! 

We ordered the devil wings, garlic noodles, Bahn Mi, and beef noodle bowl. Everything was really tasty and the devil wings are actually really spicy! They have a very extensive drink menu which was a nice surprise. It's not in Little Saigon but I thought the prices were reasonable and the food/service was good enough that I'll return!
author: Semuteh F.

description: Came here because I saw nice reviews and decor of the bars and restaurants.  Just ordered "street food" and appetizers - they were awesome, both taste and presentation.  We didn't order the dinner so I can't say how good the main courses are.  I noticed this place is not for die hard VN dishes but if you want good ambience and fun, hip place for happy hours or small group fun food the definitely it should be on your list
author: Tom V.

description:
The definition of consistent. From the food (authentic yet inspired), to the service (warm yet refined), to the ambiance (eclectic but comfortable); Co Nam has it all. Start with some Crispy Rolls and Devil Wings, move on to split a Phà for two (without a doubt the best broth in the land) and finish with the shaken beef (tender and umami). 

Capping it all off is the curated beer and wine list.  If your a novice, get a flight. If your a nerd, settle in for a session of Curiexu or La Fin Du Monde. 

This place has it all. So try it, fall in love, and give away your Friday's forever. Because there is enough here to kick the weekend off right.
author: Joe C.

description:
This is my go to neighborhood spot whenever I'm feeling Vietnamese but am too lazy to trek to the TL. I was a bit skeptical when I first entered (usually modern decor = mediocre food) but I was pleasantly surprised. On my way to the bathroom I peeked in the kitchen and saw an older Vietnamese lady behind a giant pot of broth. 

The bun rieu here is legit for being a non hole in the wall in city.
author: Christine N.

description:
Great meal. Had some surprisingly authentic dishes and ingredients that are hard to find in most Vietnamese restaurants - definitely not something that was expected at a sorta-trendy Polk Street spot. And the quality of ingredients - especially meat - was much higher than at your typical Vietnamese joint. 

Small place that can struggle to keep up with reservation times - we weren't seated until a half hour after our booked time. 

All in all it's comparable to Mau and Tin, although I'd give this spot the nod on both taste and menu diversity.
author: David C.

description:
We had a lovely impromptu dinner here on a Friday evening.  First, we checked out their happy hour (half off draft beer wraps and rolls).  We ordered a few rolls, and my fave was the fried chicken and shrimp roll - yumm!  We opted for cocktails instead of beer and our fave was the lychee martini - love lychee!  In addition, we ordered the daily street food special which was breaded beef on a stick - tasty!  And then, once we saw the dessert menu, we had to get the fried banana with ice cream and the mango sticky rice  along with a couple of hot Vietnamese coffees -- we loved both these desserts!  Lots of ooos and aahhs resulted!  

Loved the ambiance of this place with the green glass bottles overhead lamps, pictures configured in a flow on one wall, live greenery on another, and we loved the restroom sink that looked like terrace fields -- wonderful decor all around!  And service was so friendly, understanding and patient answering all of our questions.  

I will be back!  :)
author: Maile N.

description:
Basa fish claypot is a classic for any Vietnamese fusion place and this restaurant does it well. It doesn't come with rice or any sides, so I recommend the Jasmine rice, which has a very slight fresh cilantro flavor. 

This place feels trendy, rather than a homey Vietnamese comfort food kind of place. Nice decor and lighting. A combination of after-work and post-workout crowd. No wait around 7:45pm. Would come again!
author: Linda Z.

description:
We went for lunch and also ordered from the dinner menu.
Started out with beef carpaccio and wicked bun.
Both were very delicious, but wicked bun had some dried parts of the bun I had to spit out.
Then we had noodle bowl with lemon grass sautéed beef and 5 spice chicken ban mi with truffle fries. OMG best fries ever.
Fries got cold and it was still crispy.

Overall:
A bit expensive for what we ate (except carpaccio)
Very well balanced flavors (really different from other vietnamese restaurants)

We ended up spending over $70 for lunch but would do it again.
author: Yunmi J.

description:
Based on the second time of eating here, I still, hands down, think this is the best place in SF for Bun Bo Hue! It's perfection! 
Their Bo La Lot is also amazing, serving it with 'mam nem' sauce which is 100% legit Vietnamese.
author: Van-Anh N.

description:
Came here for a dinner when a friend was visiting for nyc. Overral the food was pretty good. Ambience was super dark. Service was poor. 

First, the ambience. The restaurant has nice decor. However, it was a little crowded (make an reservation!) and very dark. I am not a huge fan of dark ambience as my eyesight degrades so fast in dark so i could barely see the food.

Food: We got quite a lot of food and everything tasted good. The pork belly was the killer. The claypots (fish and chicken) were tasty, although in general the serving size was small. This is not your typical vietnamese restaurant for sure: pricer and smaller-portion.

Service was super slow. My fork was dirty and i kept asking for a new one. It is very clear that this place is understaffed.
author: Ruxin H.

description:
Great food! Shared the vegetarian spring rolls, the pork belly appetizer, the shaking beef, and (couldn't help ourselves) the mango sticky rice for dessert. The service was prompt; the food was hot and delicious. 

We didn't get drinks, but the bill came out to ~$30/person with tip, which seemed super reasonable for the amount and quality of food we devoured.
author: Megan B.

description:
Love this place! I'm big fan of Vermicelli noodle salads and this place had a great choice of options. I ended up opting for the Lemon Grass Chicken with Jasmine Rice which was delicious. I went on a Sunday night, so there was no wait. 

Its a fancy Vietnamese place, so I appreciated the change of pace from the regular whole in the wall type of Vietnamese places. I'd definitely go back with a group of friends and grab drinks and dinner.
author: Ebonie M.

description: Excellent Vietnamese restaurant. Very calm laid back environment with soft jazz soundtrack and candlelight. The food was excellent as well. Got the seafood fried rice and loved it. Not greasy at all and delicious.
author: Rick R.

description: I came here the other day to get take out and had to wait 30 minutes after arriving (on top of the 15 minutes between calling and walking to the restaurant) to receive my order. I ordered only one dish and after eating a third of the dish I noticed a fleshy wing type thing in my food which could have either been a roach or a discarded shrimp tail. I lost my appetite after that and discarded the rest of the dish. I can't say anything about the dine in experience but be wary of ordering out.
author: Ramla M.

description: Food is quite salty. In particular the pork belly and the fish hot pot, both recommendations of the waiter. The shaken beef was good, very tasty. Service was very slow and with lack of attention to the tables.
author: Javier S.

description:
Date & Time:  Tuesday September 18, 2012 @ 1pm & Sunday July 29, 2018 @ 1pm
Dining Companion:  The Husband
Scene:  Couples & Groups Gather Here in Lululemon or Off-the-Shoulder Tops & Skinny Ankle Jeans 
Music:  EDM & Techno
Decor:  The Server will Welcome You to this 49 Seat Eatery w/ Recycled Woods & Environmentally Friendly Space.  Sit in One of The Cozy Tables for Two or Bench Banquettes & Enjoy Some Good Food
Service:  Nice Bradley Cooper Dead Ringer & Sweet Server
Imbibe:  Iced & Hot Vietnamese Coffee
Devour:  Goi Mu'c(Poached Calamari Salad), Ga Nu'o'ng Ngu Vi Hu'o'ng(Grilled Fice-Spice Chicken), Heo Nu'o'ng(Grilled Pork Vermicelli), Pho w/ Steak + MeatBalls & Pork Belly Buns
Total:  $48.83 & $51.63
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
Excellent service and delicious food! Lovely venue with personal attention to design and decor which creates a welcoming and comforting ambiance...
And they have beignets!
author: Alanna Z.

description: They include 20% tips in the check and then put fields for additional tips. So we basically paid 40% in tips (!) and noticed next day when we started to venmo each other
author: Mikhail L.

description: AMAZING. Highly recommend the Beef Carpaccio, Braised Pork Belly, and Spicy Devil Wings. Great food and ambience!
author: Jerrin B.

description:
We came here during a recent trip to San Francisco since we were in the area and it was one of the few places open around Christmas that had pretty good reviews. We took note of some of the negative reviews and so we came in with slightly lowered expectations. Unfortunately, we'd still have to give this place only 2 stars.

Service: The staff was friendly enough and welcoming (as is the case with most San Francisco establishments), however, the service was incredibly slow and inefficient. Perhaps they were understaffed for the holidays, but the waiter/host took a little under 10 minutes to seat us in 1 of several open tables. He chose to spend a lot of time taking the orders of other customers who clearly were not yet ready instead of taking a mere 10 seconds to seat us. We also had to ask for water 3 times before someone brought us our glasses and a few more times in order to get refills. They were also quite inefficient in that each server could only seem to do 1 thing at a time (for example, instead of taking away empty appetizer plates along with serving the main course, they went back and forth multiple times to do each task separately).

Food: The portions were relatively large for the price. My fish pot was okay. It was a little too salty but had a good amount of spice and flavor. The pho that my girlfriend ordered, however was definitely not authentic. It tasted as if it were made with artificially flavored powder packages (similar to what you'd find in ready to eat cup noodles). It was definitely a disappointment and not something I'd recommend off the menu.

Ambiance: The place was very clean and the decor was pretty contemporary, which contrasted with the old cutout photos and magazine pages of Vietnamese culture taped along the main wall of the restaurant. 

Overall, I can't recommend this restaurant as there are several other places around the area with Viet cuisine. Just make sure that those other places are open.
author: Russell M.

description: Co Nam must be the Vietnamese term for "all our staff has run out." Made a reservation for dinner and after waiting for 5 minutes for someone to show up to either greet or seat us, I walked up to the bar where I was told to wait by the door. Dude chilling by the door couldn't seem to make up his mind if he worked there or not. We walked out.
author: Ash S.

description:
Expensive for the portion size. Great food, great drinks. However, I did feel like it was Americanized. 

Garlic noodles: nice thick noodle, but it was a bit too sweet for my liking. 

Egg rolls: delicious. Can't go wrong!

Lemongrass chicken: also very good! Didn't have that authentic taste though. 

Drinks: soju mojito comes in various flavors. A tad sweet/syrupy but overall a good buzz.
author: Katherine H.

description: I happened to stumble upon this gem because I parked in front of it, and so happy that I did! My bf and I were intrigued by the sign that said "Rustic Vietnamese food". It was still happy hour (4-6 PM) when we walked in so we ordered some drinks and skewers off of the Vietnamese Street Food menu. That menu alone is quite unique and something I have not seen before. The skewers had about 5-6 pieces of meat on them and ranged from $3-5. The calamari was cooked perfectly and not overly chewy. The chicken hearts were BOMB! For those that might be scared to try them, they taste nothing like liver or other organs but have a milder flavor more reminiscent of the dark meat of a chicken. Must try! I also ordered the ginger cocktail ($2 off during HH) and it was refreshingly spicy and citrusy but also strong as hell. The staff were really friendly and personable and they made good recommendations. I will definitely have to come back the next time I'm in town to try the burger and the noodle dishes.
author: Mymy N.

description: I was impressed is an understatement. The falvors are beyond! We had the garlic noodles and fish clay pot. I'll never be the same again hahaha we will definitely be back!!
author: Sophia G.

description: I honestly quite liked the food at Co Nam and was a relatively regular customer here. I have never written a yelp review before but had to after the horrific customer service I just experienced. I ordered a beef pho through the app Caviar and went to pick it up when the app told me my food was ready. I showed up at 7:45pm and the woman near the entrance told me to wait at the bar because my food was not ready yet. I waited for 15-20 minutes and she finally gave me my food. I took it home and the broth was luke warm and did not cook the raw beef in the soup, making it inedible. I called the restaurant and spoke to Henry and he said I would need to go through the app to receive a refund. When I did, the app's customer service rep said they contacted the restaurant and they would not be refunding me. I called Henry back and was yelled at by him saying that he did not remember seeing anyone waiting and the food was ready at 7:40pm so it is not his fault that it was cold. Before I could say anything back he hung up on me! This interaction was so unpleasant, I will never be returning to this restaurant or using the app Caviar to order food ever again. Henry would greatly benefit from some customer service training and if I were the owner I would seriously consider letting him go.
author: Jenny O.

description: Love the food. Their wicked buns were amazingly delicious and so was the garlic noodles. These dishes made me really nostalgic of Taiwanese cuisines as well since we tend to have similar ways of cooking noodles and buns. Also a great place for happy hours: great selection of drinks and appetizers and no crowds before 7pm!!
author: Claire Y.

description:
Great upscale Vietnamese joint. Atmosphere is a bit chic and quiet (may not be popular enough yet). 

Devil chicken wings are tasty but a bit sticky. The fish claypot is excellent and was by far the favorite dish. The papaya salad with shrimp ceviche is good.

Staff is friendly and attentive. Drinks are expertly prepared -- Elderflower Martini in particular.
author: Victor W.

description: I'll start of buy saying that the Vietnamese food here is pretty good!  The ambience is relaxed and the decor is very upscale.  The service was attentive and very friendly.  It was a party of 8 of us and they say is 10 minutes to closing, which was very nice of them.  Throughout the whole meal, we weren't rushed at all and my party felt like we could really take our time and enjoy the food.  The pork vermicelli noodle bowl and garlic noodles really stood out from the rest.  The drinks are strong, but unbalanced.  All in all, it was a great meal with great music! I.e. Kaskade, Above & Beyond, Armin, etc...
author: Josh S.

description:
Food quality is ok not great, their meat dishes did felt it was undercooked. Their customer service is extremely bad and consistently messes up orders. (went here twice)

Probably would not come here again...
author: Edward S.

description: Food is absolutely delicious. I recommend this spot constantly. Take out is also super painless.
author: Thomas B.

description:
So we just walked out of there after 40 minutes of wait, without any food because the waiter didn't enter our order.  They were super busy and under staffed with just one extremely inexperienced waiter and bartender who is also trying to be a waiter.  Chaos is the only way I can describe how the restaurant was managed - people next to us got their order messed up so they waited another 20 minutes to have it fixed.  The other table waited at least 10 minutes before the lone waiter brought them the menu and that's only because the patrons asked.  People were seated out of sequence.. the food was taking a long time for every table but we knew something was wrong when people who were seated at least 25 minutes after us got their appetizer.  

When we called the waiter over to check on our order, and his answer was "so what are you waiting for?" Really?!  After we told him to go check the computer and that's when he told us that the order was never entered.  Granted he said he will bump our order to the top of the line, but given that the next table waited for 20 minutes to have the correct food delivered,  we know that top of the line doesn't mean very much and left.

The waiter's excuse is that they got busy.  But I've been to restaurants where they were under staffed and still ran quite smoothly because they knew what they were doing.  This is such a pathetic establishment - has a lot to learn to live up to SF standards and anything that resembles decent customer service.
author: H. L.

description:
Social media tip: check in on foursquare and/or yelp for free thai iced tea, beignets, and wicked roll.

The free stuff we got - the beignets and wicked roll - were actually the best things we had at brunch.  Wicked roll had pork belly and was fairly delicious.

I ordered spicy devil wings (not that spicy, small portion), my friends ordered the american omelet, and vietnamese omelet - both OK, not fantastic.

Green tea there is pretty fantastic though.  And apparently the french toast is great. I would return...but order different stuff - maybe try the bahn mi and order a lot more wicked rolls. 

Not super busy but our service was kind of slow.
author: Alice Z.

description:
Our favorite Vietnamese place in SF and exceptionally good value for money. Very attentive and friendly staff too. 

Don't miss the garlic herb noodles, Brussels sprout chips, rice or noodle bowl (recommend with beef), but you won't go wrong with anything on the menu!
author: Christoffer K.

description:
TLDR: Slow service, small portions, mediocre food. 

Walked in, waited a few minutes before getting greeted and seated. Menu is pretty short, so we didn't need much time to decide. Waited some more before being able to get the waitress's attention...both the waiter and waitress were here physically but their minds were elsewhere. Couldn't get their attention even when they walked past to other tables. 
The food... I'd save my money and would rather eat somewhere else.
The waiter's friend came towards the end of our meal, and the waiter, waitress and the friend all chatted it up with the waitress's back facing us. Impossible to get her attention after that until she went to get a sip of her vino. 
Would we come back? Definitely not.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Food took forever. Appetizers came in 10-15 minutes, but entrees took almost an hour  from the time we ordered. Granted, we had a large group of 9, but come on.

Other than that, service was decent. Water was continuously refilled for the most part, they weren't stingy about limes/lemons/garnishes, the waiter was responsive.

However, when it came to pay for the bill, there were two main problems:
- Automatic 20% large party gratuity. I'm totally happy and willing to pay this when the food comes out promptly, but we were all beyond starving an hour after sitting down when the mains finally came out.
- SUPER SHADY $1 CREDIT CARD FEE...PER CARD. Not only is this ridiculously high and unexpected in an Asian Fusion-ish restaurant, but there was no warning whatsoever. We paid with 8 cards, the maximum, but the $1 fees were all loaded onto my card and I wasn't told about it until after my card had been charged. Really weird and left a bad taste in my mouth.

I normally only care about food; service, especially at Asian restaurants, is secondary. But the food wasn't amazing enough to overshadow this ridiculous $1/credit card usage charge without any notification whatsoever. Brussel sprouts, chicken wings and grilled pork bowl were decent. Bo bun hue was mediocre. So...nothing special, especially so close to the Tenderloin and the multitudes of Vietnamese options there.
author: Suana W.

description:
We came early and sat at the bar. We got to meet Trong and Henry. The food was delicious and it was a great way to spend our NYE. 

We ate:
- street food
- birds nest
- garlic noodles
- shaken beef
- bass clay pot 
- beignets 
- fried bananas

And somehow, between the two of us, we seemed to finish most of it. 

Side note: cucumber martinis. Purchase 4. You won't be sorry.
author: Jessica M.

description: The service didn't work well and we have to wait all drinks and our main course almost an hour. Food taste very good and place is nice. But overall we like the Co Nam.
author: Jouni H.

description:
I ordered their Bo Bun Hue and took it home. It was awful. There was a gigantic bone with tons of cartilage. Never Never again. 

The only reason why I'm giving them two stars is because I only tried one dish and they were really fast.
author: Colleen F.

description: Nicely done interiors, and a cozy ambience. Ordered Basa fish claypot and Beef sautéed lemongrass rice bowl. Both dishes were very flavorful. They have a good selection of craft beer and cocktails as well.
author: Philip T.

description: the pho here are soooo good it's not like anything other pho i've tried. even my mom liked it and she's a picky pho eater aha!
author: Hop N.

description: This place has the best beef vermiceli bowls. The crispy rolls and pho are also good. Great place.
author: Vince M.

description:
Good food! Their waitress Kiran is awesome, which made the experience even better. 

I got the banh mi and just the bread by itself was delicious and fresh. You know that crackle sound fresh bread makes when you crack it? It was like that. 

Perfect portions. At first when the food came out, my American stomach said 'what that's such a small portion'. But hell no it wasn't. It was perfect. 

The Brussels sprout chips were a miss. I don't think they were worth $8. 

The Thai iced tea was a little too sweet for my taste as well.
author: D M.

description:
3.5 stars.

I always walk by Co Nam on Polk and wonder if it's any good, since I'm a little critical of fancy Vietnamese fusion restaurants, but I enjoyed the food and dining experience here.

The service was great - our waiter was very attentive and friendly. I almost expected a hipster-douchey attitude (*cough* Mau), but was pleasantly surprised. We walked in early and were seated right away.

They have a nice list of wine, cocktails and draft beers, which were reasonably priced. Overall, the food was good with some high and low points, but I thought some dishes were a little on the expensive side for what they were.

Crispy rolls - tasted just like an ordinary fried egg roll.
Bo Tai Chanh (Beef carpaccio) - Good, but lacking in flavor.
Braised pork belly - Good, well braised and saucy, but the dish could have used an acidic element like pickles, to cut all the fattiness.
Fish Claypot - The fish was good and not too saucy, but this dish could've used some additional veggies or tofu.
Shaken beef - I've had better. 

Overall, food was decent and service was excellent. I would go back to try other claypot dishes.
author: Vivian H.

description:
My husband had a gig next door at Red Devil Lounge so we all (bandmates & significant others) decided to go to CoNam for dinner. We were first a group of 6 which became a group of 10. 

All the tables were occupied already with the exception of a couple that had the "reserved" sign on it.  We said we had no reservation but they didn't turn us away. I was immediately impressed. He took a few minutes to review his reservations for the night and ended accommodating us! 

We all enjoyed our orders.  Lots of yums going around the table.  I personally had the beef carpaccio & garlic and herb noodles.

Beef carpaccio: surprisingly good.  Beef seemed "fresh" with the correct carpaccio texture. Good balance of acid, sweet and savory. My husband agreed it was very good and he's not huge on raw beef.

Herb garlic noodle: very tasty. Not too garlicky. Good flavor.  Good chewy noodle texture. Very satisfying. 

Others had noodle bowls (some had beef, chicken, and veggie).. All said good. All bowls empty.

Almost forgot to mention the drinks... I had the elderflower martini. Made with soju and sake. Very light and refreshing. Strong enough to do its job :). Now one of my favorite drinks.
author: kate w.

description:
Super Average. The rating is actually a 2.5. Let me break it down.

Decor: Starting with the best here. The decor is very nice. A perfect blend of Vietnamese decorations with a modern decor. Simple yet comfortable seating.

Bar: Good effort. Didn't try the cocktails. But the beer selection is a wide range. But that's really yet. If you are serious about your beer, you know this is probably not the place to come to. They have a selection, but any beer connoisseur would quickly dismiss it as mediocre. They're IPA's especially are weak. 

Service: Again, good effort. Very friendly service and happy to help and make you feel welcomed. But, don't expect great service. To give you an example, if you order two dishes which are pretty much the same, don't expect them to point it out. To give you another example, if you order a dish such as veggie chips, don't expect them to point it out while ordering that it indeed has fish sauce. There's definitely potential here for great service. It's just not there yet. 

Food: This department was unfortunately the least impressive. I like fusion, when in fact there is really some fusion. Here is it basically vietnamese food taken down a notch in flavors, spice etc. I would say its vietnamese Americanized rather than any Vietnamese fusion. Some of the dishes we ordered tasted pretty much the same served differently. The whole heart and soul of vietnamese food was missing. Also, don't order the iced coffee expecting the nice little drip. This iced coffee is more...think Iced mocha at Starbucks. Literally the only dish that tasted good, actually great were the chicken wings which luckily was the first one at the table. So that made the evening not so bad. It was all downhill after that and came crashing down when we got the bill. ~$30 per person for which we could have eaten three meals at a great vietnamese restaurant. 

In summary, i'll definitely come back when maybe someone tells me its changed drastically or if somehow I become the kind of person who wants to eat vietnamese food but scared to go to some place in the outer richmond or little saigon. But not for now.
author: Karthick S.

description: This restaurant is adorable! I was looking for a Vietnamese restaurant that also had delicious drinks and they delivered! My boyfriend and I ordered the pork spring rolls, bacon wrapped mushrooms, beef lemongrass rice bowl and the banh mi. The rice bowl was my favorite thing! It had so much flavor and the pickled vegetables were the perfect contrast. My boyfriend order a delicious martini and they had a great selection of wines (two different glasses of rose to choose from!). This is a great date spot!
author: Jesse F.

description: This place is dope. Best banh mi chicken sandwich I ever had. Fries are great. Friendly staff. My only complaint is that there was one hidden pepper in my sandwich that was spicier than holy shit. 10/10 will go here again next time I'm in the area.
author: Phil I.

description: I love this restaurant. It's consistently great, fresh food and friendly, efficient service. It's a bit loud and I have to yell to speak to my friend but, that seems to be the trend in SF these days. Love the cloth napkins and nice white dishes. Food is presented in a nice way too.
author: Kimberley L.

description: Thanks for responding, nice to know owners read and accept feedback.  And glad to know you donate leftover food to the needy, I will return just for that reason.  I arrived and sat at the bar around 4pm.  And the shrimp roll could not have been prepared to order as it came out within 2 minutes of me ordering it, she hadn't even poured my glass of wine yet.  I understand siracha is a staple in Asian cooking, but shows no creativity when you just pick up a bottle and squeeze.
author: William M.

description: Co Nam is absolutely delightful! The food is impeccable, fresh, and full of flavor every time we've visited (which is A LOT). We've never had a bad experience with service, timing, or the food. It's got a charming appeal, low light atmosphere and really cool photos on the wall. The staff is always polite, attentive, and knowledgeable. Christina (I could be spelling wrong or have wrong name) is wonderful, she's so sweet and has made our experience there even better.
author: Kelly B.

description: I tried Co Nam for the first time through UberEats and was pretty pleasantly surprised!  I ordered the Bun Bo Hue (BBH) which was maybe a 8 out of 10 compared to some more authentic BBHs I have had in Seattle.  The catfish clay pot was perhaps a 10 out of 10 - super crispy and the perfect amount of sweet and salty, when eaten with rice. The quail wings were interesting - the sake was a little unexpected and kind of overpowering. I would give them a 7 out of 10.  Overall pretty amazing for a delivery order.  Uber Eats was fast and delivered in about 30 minutes and my food was still hot.
author: Jane M.

description: Stopped by this place for dinner on the way home from work with a friend and thought it was great stop. Really small spot but we were sat right away. We ordered cocktails and pork spring rolls to start. Neither of us were crazy about the cocktails but spring rolls were absolutely delicious! I actually didn't drink mine and got a glass of wine instead which he didn't charge me for.. very nice of them. Definitely get the spring rolls if you need a healthier appetizer. I ordered the pork chop as my meal which were two large chops and cooked well in a light sauce with a side of rice. Definitley cooked well but kinda wish I had something green on my plate... I recommend ordering a side to split. My friend ordered a beef vermicelli bowl and she thought it was delicious but wished there were more toppings and less noodles. I recommend stopping by!
author: Aryn C.

description:
Amazing food. The sweet and sour soup is possibly the best soup I've ever had in my life. It's not traditional sweet / sour. It's something amazing! 

Be warned this place is often understaffed in the front of house so it could take a while to get your food or be seated.
author: John W.

description: This has recently become one of my go to local spots for Vietnamese. I usually take out but the restaurant itself is a tight squeeze but modern and inviting. The food has been a solid experience each time: we have tried and loved the crispy rolls, vegetable stir fry, vegetarian rice bowl, and noodle bowl. I'll be back to try their clay pot dishes but I'm just really happy there is a solid place like this on Polk to compete with the other Vietnamese spots - the variety of menu options is a nice change.
author: Derek S.

description:
Surely the most expensive Vietnamese food I've ever had, but it was a pretty good and fun experience. The atmosphere is very cozy, reminded me to places in NYC. 

I love the concept of "rustic" Vietnamese food. flavors are very traditional but all the dishes have a refreshing and modern twist. I appreciated the full bar, wines and beer variety. Unusual for Asian spots. We had glasses of prosseco, the fish pot, the pork buns and the lemongrass chicken. Everything was delicious.

The service was great - granted we came at a time when was not crowded. and I mean really great! our server was super friendly and always checked on us throughout our meal.

I loved everything about it - minus the price...I spent 45 dollars (with tip) with drinks, a shared appetizer and an entree. Not happy with the high prices, but again, the atmosphere was great as well as the service.
author: Elizabeth D.

description: Very quaint place with indoor and outdoor seating. Sunday brunch menu was varied and the pork rice bowl was excellent. Prices were very reasonable.
author: Andrea G.

description:
Basa Fish Clay Pot (5/5) - Served in a sesame/honey sauce that perfectly complements the very lightly breaded white fish, which was cooked to perfection.  Does not come with a side of Jasmine Rice (which I suggest ordering).
Quail appetizer (4/5) - Split out onto individual serving sticks to make it easier to share.  Good app choice for meat-a-tarians.
Pork Vermicelli (4/5) - Good fresh dish though the cuts of meat were my least favorite part.  If I ordered it again I would try the chicken.
I would order all three things again (and have already gone back for the Basa fish clay pot).  All in all a good restaurant at a very reasonable price.
author: Tyler G.

description: Awesome place, pho was amazing and on my list for top 3. Bartender Caitlyn was awesome and owner was great. Will be back for sure! See you guys soon.
author: Marissa C.

description: Great knowledgable staff!  Street food menu is on fire and the beer selection/cocktail list is as well.  HH specials from 4-6 make this well priced spot a fantastic deal.
author: Sheehan M.

description:
(See pics) Review #1299. Solid 4+ stars for the delicious Vietnamese food. According to elite Yelper friend Peter L who has the better knowledge of the cuisine, he stated the food was authentic and home style as we were enjoying the dinner.

Quick note on the name. It's actually Co Nam but Yelp has it spelled as Conam.Was not able to find the restaurant directly on Open Table but the link from Yelp was correct. So take note if you try to make a reservation.

Beef carpaccio was crisp and refreshing with very thinly sliced chilled and very red beef, laid out beautifully like a piece of art with scallions, and strips of mint leaves.

The claypot fish was excellent, a Vietnamese signature dish well made.

Sweet and sour soup was not the Chinese style. It had more of a sour taste that kicks up your appetite and was actually a clear soup.

The green beans, spring rolls and sauteed beef were all tasty and tasted very home style cooking..

The alcoholic drinks here were on the slightly sweet side but you can definitely still taste the alcohol.

The dessert soup was more of rice pudding with taro cubes mixed in it. It was a very warm dish and was very tasty without being too sweet. Definitely a great highlight.

They also served house made Vietnamese yogurt with raspberry as well as blueberries. Each was chilled in a concealed container. It tasted more like a Greek yogurt, as Peter has suggested.

The hot banana cakes was warm and delicious. Of course a Vietnamese meal is not one without a Vietnamese style coffee. And it definitely was a good drink to keep me wired for the rest of the evening out!

Service was very nice and our server was very humorous and tried to answer any questions we had, especially on the restaurant name.
author: T L.

description: Good drinks for a very reasonable price. Enoki mushroom is very well made.
author: G T.

description: Cocktails were ok but not spectacular. Appetizers were dry and small. Meals were the best bc of the meats being cooked great but still needed more flavor  lemongrass basil chicken was the best out of all. Good restaurant but will not do it again with so many great ones in the area
author: Lynda N.

description:
The food is delicious here.  Love the claypot fish, eggrolls, sticky rice, and even the sandwich.  Yummy braised pork belly if you want to splurge, but everything is a must try.  

The decor is quite rustic.  Service is excellent.  We had a big group and everything was served promptly.  Our water glasses were always full which I look for in terms of service.  

Will definitely come back again and already craving for their beef carpaccio.
author: Helen O.

description:
If you don't know what to get from Co Nam's menu, I'd highly recommend their Beef Carpaccio and Braised Basa Clay Pot.  Even though I live in the South Bay where Vietnamese cuisine is abundant, I wouldn't mind coming back here just for the unforgettable taste and texture of these dishes.    

Friendly service, cleanliness, and new interesting decor also makes me a big fan!
author: Bobby L.

description: Very clean beef filet pho, love habanero or spicy peppers instead of sriacha. Awesome fresh veggie rolls (sans noodles), place is by Bobs ;)
author: Caroline L.

description: I've been to Co Nam five times now, and it is reliably very delicious and a fun environment. Great beers, great food. Even was a part of a group that rented out the entire restaurant once, and that was a blast too. Highly recommended!
author: David V.

description:
Easter sunday comes and I'm randomly in SF, on Polk, looking for a place to eat dinner with other atheist/orphans friends, when we come across this Viet place. Yelp it and good reviews surface, so we open their door and step into the best ending for a great day spent together. 

The ambiance is chill, a bit dark in the back so we sit closer to the window, though the allure of the living wall and dark wood keeps my eyes returning to look towards the rear, slightly wishing we had sat further back. 

The waitress is smiley and immediately on my good side, and as she single-handedly took care of the 12 tables she was on top of our requests, so it was impressive. 

The food - we got crispy spring rolls, which can hardly be bad, and yet these were so good it was like a krispy kreme compared to a regular donut. Then the rice bowls, I had 5 spice chicken, and it was delicious (kudos for having a gluten free sauce replacement). I could only eat half, and so I also get to look forward to repeating part of this experience tomorrow. Def a tasty Viet meal.
author: Candace B.

description:
Came here once with a group of friends after a colleague recommended it and found myself craving it the next week so ended up here again for a dinner with my mama when she came into town. Its on the small side, going for a classier Vietnamese vibe. The servers were all extremely friendly and on our mother-daughter date night the server even offered to sample various wines if we were interested in making a wine selection for the evening...which we were!

With friends we ordered:
Apps:
grilled sugarcane shrimp 
shrimp pops
spicy devil wings- delicious
Meals:
basa fish claypot- delicious
grilled pork vermicelli bowl- delicious

With the mama we ordered the grilled pork vermicelli once again (thats what I'd been craving) and she had the clay pot medley accompanied by a lovely cab sauv. I LOVE this vermicelli bowl, so flavorful. I finished it. I rarely finish anything. My mother really enjoyed the claypot medley as well, which I liked but wasn't as much my vibe. 

All in all- great service, delicious food, apps are a bit on the pricey side compared to portion. Great ambiance for a date night.
author: Nicole Z.

description:
I really like the food here but unfortunately can't overlook the last 3 times that I ordered food there was something wrong each time. This is a review for delivery only. 

The first time I was overcharged by $25. The second time I ordered the mango panna cotta dessert but it had mold on top. This time I ordered thai iced tea but the milk used had gone bad.  It tasted disgusting and some of it was curdled. 

Get your act together co nam!!!  Otherwise I fully enjoyed the wicked buns, vermicelli noodle bowls, and the filet mignon.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I actually kind of love the idea of americanized cuisine, so I was curious about Co Nam. The place is pretty small (we actually missed it the first time we walked past), but the decor/interior is cute and pretty nice for a trendy date night or girls' night. 

Food:
1) Braised pork belly - delicious, and I personally hate the texture of fat. Very tender and great flavor.

2) Beef carpaccio - not my favorite because the taste was a little bit 'off' overall, but the quality of the meat was there.

3) Medley & basa claypot - Basa did not come with any side of rice, although the medley did. Both were tasty, and the portions were just right paired with one or two appetizers. 

Overall, not a bad dining experience. It was definitely americanized, but since I knew that going in, it's not a bad thing at all. The flavors were definitely there, and while it is slightly expensive for Vietnamese food, the decor/interior definitely makes up for the difference.
author: Emily Z.

description:
I was super excited to try this obviously americanized viet place. It looked so cute and cozy! Lots of friends meeting up and dates, it seemed like.

I was feeling sick and hung over, so I ordered a tomato based noodle soup, and my sister ordered papaya salad.

Both were.... pretty hard to eat.

You know how you feel kind of upset when you get full after eating something super so-so?

That's exactly what I felt...

Plus it was kind of pricy for what it was.

It was really loud in there, it was really difficult to have a conversation with my friend from across the table and even my sister who was sitting right next to me.

Service was slow, but the servers were really nice, I just assume they were a bit chaotic that night. It was surprisingly busy.........
author: Alexis P.

description:
Walked to this place as it was near our motel.  The food was very good!  I had the noodle bowl with chicken.  It is a lot of food and very flavorful.  I wanted a beer but wasn't sure which one.  The server was nice and let me try a few of them to help me decide.

The place has a nice look and the bathroom was clean, which is a bonus.
author: John C.

description: Seriously the most amazing food and service I've had in San Francisco. The mojitos were so great, I had the citrus one and my friend had the passion fruit so great!! Highly recommend to all, super trendy and great music
author: Brooke N.

description:
We were able to score reservations on a Friday night very easily.  I knew maybe it wasn't a good sign.  Cute, updated space on Polk but with great Asian food all around us it fell short.  

Our table shared everything - 
Roll sampler - nothing special
Daily street food - chicken heart - I didn't try it
Green papaya salad - You can't really mess up this classic dish but it lacked a lot of the flavor & heat that it would normally have.  Super disappointing. 
Basa Fish Clayplot - it was just ok  
Bird's Nest - it was just fried noodles - nothing special and lacked flavor
Brussel sprout chips - standard 

Nothing stood out and I wouldn't recommend this place - sorry.
author: Meredith K.

description: Over price for the quality of the food they are serving. The spring roll was dry and not fresh. Anyway if you are looking for legit Vietnamese food, this is not the prefect spot for it.
author: Mikey C.

description: Service was SUPERB.  Food was Grade-A.  Got the Vietnamese sandwich and loved how tender and marinated the chicken was! Hit the spot! There were about three other things I wanted to try, so I'll have to see about next time  ABSOLUTELY LOVE THIS PLACE.
author: Fawn M.

description:
We used to come here very often, this place was our fav place in Nob Hill but I unfortunately have to update my past review because the quality has decreased dramatically during the past few months.
I believe the staff changed (have been seeing new faces for at least 3-4 months) and it impacted the quality of the food and the service very badly.
The service is now very slow, waiters and chefs are not organized and seem overwhelmed every single time (at rush hours or not), appetizers are served after the entrees are, and the food doesn't taste nearly as good as what it used to.
To go orders are now missing at least an ingredient or item 100% of the time, and our last order was terrible: a wicked bun was missing pork belly (how can you forget about the main ingredient?!), garlic herb noodles tasted more garlicky than anything else (couldn't finish them).
Portions are also much smaller than they used to be. I know covering rent, employee salaries, etc. gets tougher and tougher on the city, but this is in my opinion not a reason why quality should be impacted this much.
Sorry Co Nam, but you won't see us again for a little while...
author: Morgan L.

description:
CoNam is a somewhat upscale Vietnamese joint with a clean, modern space and pretty good quality food.

As a fan and often-diner of Vietnamese cuisine, the food wasn't amazing but it certainly was good. I would give the food a solid 4/5 rating. 

The clay pot chicken breast and veggies was good, the spring roll was fresh and tasty, and the vermicelli noodles were reportedly pretty good according to my friends.

I like the ambiance; very sleek, cool, and chic. Definitely a chill place to take a girl out on a dinner date for food, wine, and ambiance. Didn't feel rushed at any point, even though the restaurant is on the smaller side (maybe 10 tables?).

Overall, a cool spot. I'll probably come back again.
author: Roy C.

description:
The restaurant is freezing. I wore my coat and scarf the whole time. They couldn't close the door because there was a ventilation problem, but this has been going on since I first went there months ago.

On the food side 
Wicked buns - fantastic, don't go without ordering
Calamari salad - meh - it isn't pan fried or grilled so tastes a bit slimy, although is probably quite healthy
Chicken liver street food - pretty good
Shrimp lollipop street food - good
author: Lizbeth S.

description: Absolutely fantastic Happy Hour from 4-6pm on weekdays. $2 Off Draft Beers and 25% off Appetizers! Applicable at the bar or for dine in- fabulous!
author: Veronica S.

description: Best Pho my partner and I have had in ages. Definitely check it out if you are a fan of Vietnamese food!
author: Ben H.

description:
I had just helped my friend move into her new apartment in Nob HIll and we were starving and wanted to try out a new restaurant nearby. We saw Co Nam and decided to try it out.. We came on a Saturday afternoon around 3:00pm and it was a bit empty. 

Our waiter seemed really busy for some reason, although there were only 3 other tables seated. Once we sat down, we checked in on Yelp and saw that there was a special for a free Thai Iced Tea and when we told our server we wanted them, he told us to hold on and ran to the back. We thought this was pretty rude since he had just come over to our table to give us the menus and we weren't asking for a lot. 

After taking our orders, he came back and told us 2 out of the 4 items we ordered RAN OUT. The 2 items were a banh mi (vietnamese sandwich) and bone marrow. How can you run out of a sandwich at 3pm on a Saturday?? We decided to order crispy rolls instead. We waited and waited for our rolls and they never came! We had to remind our server that we had ordered it and he went to go check on it. 

I'm giving 2 stars because the service was not very attentive, they ran out of certain items on their menu but didn't note it, and they forgot one of our orders. 

I'm not sure if I will be coming back here...
author: Monica W.

description: Overpriced and underwhelming food and crappy service. My fiancé just said he wishes he could go back in time and go anywhere else. I second that.
author: erin l.

description:
The food is good and reasonably priced. Fresh roles are delicious and they obviously use good ingredients.

Service was poor - I was sat for 10 minutes without a menu, had to ask for water repeatedly and my plates weren't cleared even when I settled check.
author: Emma D.

description:
Exceedingly slow service and mediocre food.

Have been eyeing the place for a while.  Had good impressions upon first entering the restaurant: clean, minimalist decor, cool music, trendy atmosphere.  We started with the broiled shrimp roles which were somewhat flavorless unless you soak them up heavily with the peanut sauce. The papaya salad (with tofu) was fine -- nothing to rave about but also nothing wrong with it.  For entrees, we had fish clay pot and a bird's nest noodle dish with seafood.  Both were just ok.  Flavors in general a bit simple and bland for my taste; I generally expect more layered and herbal accents with Vietnamese food, but I understand that they are probably catering more to the hip and fusion food crowd.  Price was high for the food.

My main gripe was the exceedingly slow service.  Food came out very slowly.  Water was unfilled for most of the meal.  On the weeknight that I went, there were two wait staff (one or both doubling as bartender) and a busboy (whom I saw rarely -- suspect he was working in the kitchen too). They just looked really overwhelmed for such a small place. Don't think I'll need to visit this place again.
author: Ray H.

description:
Had the skewers (Chicken hearts and liver) which where pretty tasty...the Bun Bo Hu is probably the best hangover remedy I've had, vertu flavorful broth base..

Small spot but will definitely come back
author: Cam V.

description:
This is a trendy Americanized (and priced) Vietnamese place. If you want something more authentic, go south on Larkin and pay 3 bucks for your smelly plastic seat.

The wings were phenomenal. The street food was great. I service was fab and I can't wait to try more off the menu!
author: Monika M.

description: Best Pho I've had on this side of 19th Ave! :) Everything we ordered was just savory & tasty! I wish I could've tried more items on the menu!!! Will definitely come back! Thanks for the recommendations Henry!
author: Carol J.

description:
Decided to come here for an early dinner Sat eve (6:30PM) with bf.  We started with the sugar cane shrimp which was mediocre - it was basically two rolls with scant shrimp (and it was pastey shrimp versus real shrimp) and all we could taste was lettuce and dough.

Next up, I had the veggie stir fry with tofu - meh, nothing to recall and I thought was overpriced at $14 for tofu and veggies.  Could've added some garlic/ginger and a more exciting sauce? You know, caramel soy or something?

BF had the sautéed filet mignon which was really confusing because it was sautéed with french fries (not freshly cut - the frozen kind since they were dry and lifeless).  It's the strangest dish I've ever seen in a Vietnamese restaurant that's for sure.  You had to mix some sauce with salt and pro it over and even then it's still confusing and why would you want to stir fry filet mignon till it's grey?

I had an interesting experience in the bathroom where they had a sink hole strain/drainer that was plugged up and caused standing water in the sink.  The drainer looked like someone had puked in it so I had to let the manager know about that.

They seemed to have spruced up the decor compared to the previous Moroccan restaurant that was there but you can see it was a minimal investment.  

Look, will this place stay in business? I think it will, at least longer than the previous two restaurants at that location.  What bugs me is that it's just mediocre food at jacked up prices in a hip decor so it will attract a young Polk Street crowd.  I'd be off elsewhere before I come back here to again.
author: Favoloso M.

description:
All anyone wants when they go out for dinner is to be unknowingly served something they have told staff they are allergic too. AMIRITE?

I battled with what rating to give this place, but ended at a 2.

The food and decor was nice enough, but a fundamental service error really took over the whole experience.

A group of us ordered the 'selection of rolls' entrée and my friend confirmed when ordered, and when placed on the table that they didn't contain shellfish as he is allergic. I was in another conversation and saw him eating the crispy rolls that I remember on the menu saying they had shrimp in them.

There was obviously a bit of concern at this point, as a shellfish allergy isn't like a headache, it leads to hours of vomiting. We told the next waiter who came over about the error, and he said sorry it is her first night. (Which didn't actually seem to be true because she knew the menu back to front and took our oder for 7 people without writing anything down). He then asked if we wanted to order something else (LOL). They made no compensation for a pretty massive error. 

It's important to note this wasn't a picky SF eater - we weren't requesting kale grown while having nursery songs played to it, its a stock standard allergy and something restaurants should really be competent at dealing with!
author: Mitchell S.

description:
Simple, clean and healthy dishes in perfect proportions that are not overpriced. I think that sums it up.
Got the Squid street food $3
Banh Mi - AMAZING!!! - $11
Chicken hearts and liver - $3 each. Chicken hearts were good, but liver a bit too strong.
author: Dhruv L.

description: The best shaken beef dish in town. And that's saying something, given the competition. This is the spot for great food and positive service. A highly recommended experience.
author: bryan o.

description:
This 1 star is for service.

My gf and I entered into a reasonably busy dining room, and didnt get seated for 5 minutes, we just stood there awkwardly. When we were seated, we became ghosts. The host (Manager/owner?) walked away hastily as soon as we were seated. 15 minutes go by and hes chatting up the table next to us and seemingly glad handing them. 

I have no problem with that, in fact I like it when the staff goes an extra mile to make customers feel welcome, but not when im seated next to them and havent even been given menus or water after 15+ Minutes.

After I stop him as hes walking past me and get the menu/drinks, I wait another 10 minutes before I have to literally interrupt him as hes striding past our table to place the order. By this time the restaurant was empty so there was no reason to believe they were busy. 
There were several other staff hovering around the back area, so im not sure why neither of them helped. 

The food was ok, the buns were good  but it would have been nice to have been offered 2 or 4 buns since 1 order gave 3. Our table was only 2. (Some restaurants will do that) 
The bun bowls were tasty, but overpriced. 

Overall the food was good if not overpriced, but the service made me feel like I was unwelcome. Chopped liver. It doesnt make sense to have to beg a restaurant to take my business.
author: Justin I.

description:
Hands down this is one of the best restaurants in SF! 
My husband and I eat here at least once a week! The food is always top notch and so is the service. We have come to know everyone who works here and we feel like and are treated like family when we arrive.
We highly recommend the wicked buns, garlic noodles, filet mignon and french fries, and definitely the beignets! Price point is spot on for the food.
Good for a nice dinner or group dinner.
author: Melisa S.

description: Delicious, over priced comfort food. Not sure if it's worth paying for such humble ingredients, but it was delicious.
author: Ana B.

description:
Pleasantly surprised.

First off, forget about Pho, this place doesn't have any. Still want good/trendy Vietnamese food while you're out on Polk? Co Nam's definitely worth a stop.

We ordered the filet mignon skewers, a beet salad, and two different soups. All were delicious, filling and fairly-priced. The service was top notch. Attentive, fast and pleasant, no complaints there.

Do note the place can get really loud, so if you want a quiet dinner date, skip Co Nam.

All in all, a great little "higher-end" Vietnamese place with good food, fair prices and good service.
author: Teiki K.

description:
Went for lunch and had the Vegetarian Spring Roll - one of the best spring rolls I've tried. Then ordered the Grilled n' Marinated Japanese Eggplant Carrot - it was so flavorful. (Keep in mind it's small so order to share as an appetizer.)
Grilled Five-Spice Chicken - if you've ever been to Cordon Bleu Vietnamese Restaurant on California Street this will sound familiar. This is just a fresher, probably more healthy, version and I loved it!
author: Jenna P.

description: Had dinner here on 9.27.14. Food overall was tasty but nothing too remarkable, though the duck heart was a treat. I would return to try other dishes.
author: Frank L.

description:
The decor is nice.  The food is ok, but nothing special.  The prices are high compared to most Vietnamese restaurants.  

I ordered the mussels entree.  What they brought was really more of an appetizer.  It was six (sm/one bite) mussels on the half shell, no rice or anything more so it wasn't filling, and I sat there starving watching everyone else eat (the pictures shown here have mussels about twice the size).  I feel like either the description should be changed so you know what you're really getting, or the waiter should have warned me that it was such a small portion.  I was pretty disappointed in this place.
author: Tonie C.

description:
This place was good. I went with my boyfriend on Friday, and the decor and service was awesome. We had a super-friendly host and waiter. The food was so-so, if only because I am not a courageous eater. We got bahn mi (which was great), and some kind of soup with ox tail and blood sausage (which grossed me out, but BF enjoyed), and the filet mignon in sauce (again-- just OK).

Will probably go back and try out some less-interesting dishes next time we're on Polk.
author: Sam C.

description:
My girlfriend has a proud and profoundly refined aesthetic, and we often let decor and design help drive our restaurant choices.  The very first thing she uttered on clearing the doorway of Co Nam was truly high praise:  "This place has the best look of any restaurant I have seen in this city."   

The look was composed of several distinct features: a lush, deep brown wood slat wall on one side; a beautiful three-dimensional (living?) green wall in the back that was cut into a pattern resembling the aerial view of Vietnamese rice terraces; and a diagonal array of old portrait and landscape postcards on the wall behind the tables.  Even the sink in the bathroom was unique, as the bowl was carved into the shape and painted the colors of rice terraces.  I have a special fondness for rice terraces.  One of my companions thought the sink was impractical:  Oh well, it worked for me, putting form over function.

The food here is solid as well, offering pleasantly divergent renditions of classic Vietnamese cuisine.  Take the cool and fresh spring rolls packed with shrimp that had been grilled on sugarcane, a truly sublime preparation that I make a bee-line for each time I go Vietnamese.  We loved our bun, a large bowl of rice noodles buried under a plentiful portion of grilled pork and topped generously with the requisite julienne of carrots and cucumber and crushed peanuts, all doused in nuoc cham.  
Our second entree, a chicken and green bean stir fry with ginger and coconut, had great promise but underwhelmed us due to the insufficiently aromatic sauce.  

Other menu items that looked good but didn't make the cut on our first visit included the grilled mussels and the banh mi.  Another sojourn to this Russian Hill spot may be in the works for the near future.
author: Derek W.

description: Very friendly and attentive waitstaff, nice interior. I had the Chicken Claypot - delish.
author: Ian M.

description:
Came in for a late dinner on a Friday night. While the ambiance and service were enjoyable, the food just didn't impress me.  We tried the steamed pork buns.  Anything with pork belly should be dripping with flavor...this was not.  We ate them, but they didn't really do much for me. 

Next was the claypot medley which also was in some desperate need of some flavor.  Loved the ambiance but hoping for some more impressive dishes if I make a return visit :)
author: Brianna M.

description:
We enjoyed a delightful dinner date here. All the food was great, there is not a single thing I wished was different at all. We had the Wicked Buns, I could eat hundreds of them. We had the devil wings, also spot on and I really liked the basil that was sprinkled on top of those. For entrees we tried the Shaken Beef and the noodles with pork. The beef was so tender and flavorful, it came with a salt, pepper, and lime dipping sauce that I totally plan to copy at home. The cold rice noodles where refreshing, but I want to go back to try their fried egg noodles.

Great ambiance and service. I would recommend this place to my foodie-est of friends!
author: Halley S.

description:
I usually never write Yelp review but my god was my experience here abysmal. My girlfriend and I popped in here for a quick brunch. With the restaurant less than half filled, we were promptly seated and waited to quite attentively. We ordered the beignets and Vietnamese iced coffee which were quite good. Things quickly went downhill after this however. 

We ordered the Bun Bo Hue and the chicken rice bowl with a crispy roll on top. They ran out of Bun Bo Hue -- no big deal, we substituted with a banh mi. After about 30 minutes of no food, we started noticing that guests who were seated after us were being served. It was then that the waiter informed us, unapologetically, that the kitchen lost our ticket and to reconfirm our order. That's it. No "I'm sorry for keeping you waiting" or anything. 

Anyways, at this point we're still trying to be understanding. Things happen, we'll just be patient. Our food finally came out after an additional 30 minutes and our patience (and hunger) was just about to give out. Again, fine; things happen we just wanted to eat and get out and on with our day at this point. However, the chicken rice bowl with crispy roll on top that was given to us was neither a rice bowl (had vermicelli) nor did it have a crispy roll. You would think with an hour plus to get the food out you would at least check to see if the order was correct. 

I'm just frustrated at this point and try to grab the attention of the waiter, who takes his sweet time getting here. I explain that hey, the order was wrong, it's been an hour plus since we got here and I just want to pay for the beignets and leave. Again, the waiter was very unapologetic and gave excuses that the kitchen staff has language barriers and that brunch was very busy -- it was less than half full when we got there!! I'm just so livid at this point I have lost all appetite completely. We left without even touching the food, the only small redeeming portion of this experience was that we were given a comp on the coffee and beignets. 

I'm very frustrated because all the other reviews indicate great service and food, and the food really did look delicious! I wish I could have given it a real try but at this point I no longer can give this establishment my business, and I strongly discourage anyone else from doing so as well.
author: Chris C.

description: Wow! This place was the one restaurant we visited twice while visiting San Francisco. Andrew, our server, not only recognized us, he paid for our "wicked buns" which were incredible! The best banh mi I've ever had. So nice, so good, so worth it. Also, while you are here, try the clay pot medley. Insanely delicious!!!
author: Kyle H.

description: Big disappointment in the food!! There's no mushroom in that bacon mushroom wrap. The service was bad and the server was arrogant. The bacon was so thick and greasy that it just ruined our appetite for the entire meal. Not coming back again. Plus this place people don't really wash their hands either as there is no soap in the bathroom. When I asked for some, Henry the douche told me that their workers don't wash their hands before cooking. I am highly concerned about the cleanliness of this restaurant. Now I just am very disgusted after eating here. Stay away from this restaurant unless you want bad food bacteria infection.
author: Yumi Y.

description: Service was earnestly friendly and well-intentioned but still frustrating enough to dampen the evening. All servers, at the behest of their manager, refused several requests to close the door to deal with a cold draft blowing through the restaurant, table surfaces were left sticky with menus placed on top of them.
author: katherine c.

description:
I work down the street from here, but had never thought to go in for Lunch.

I was pleasantly surprised last week when some friends and I stopped in. We all selected one of the cold noodle bowls, and it was honestly the best dish I've had for a quick lunch in a long time.

Our sever gave us fresh beers when the ones we ordered were running low on CO2, and was super friendly. 

It ended up being a little pricey ($70 lunch for three of us with a drink each), but was super delicious and I will be going back.
author: Kayla B.

description:
Co Nam has SOLID vietnamese food. Their garlic noodles are delicious. Their claypot with the chicken medley is also really yummy. I liked their basa fish claypot as well as all of their appetizers.

The decor is really modern and love the wall in the back. Service the three times we have gone has also been rock solid.  I'm so glad Co Nam opened up on Polk!
author: Natalie S.

description:
I've been to Co Nam a bunch. The food is awesome. My last experience there, I was seated at the bar. If I had a choice, I would have avoided it knowing what I know now.

I'm not sure if it is the length of the bar or the person serving the bar BUT the service was horrendous. My friend and i was sat at the end of the bar and the woman couldn't hear us order, it took 30 minutes before we could even order a drink. My wine came after I already finished my meal. The man next to me ordered take-out and he was there an hour before we even sat down, waiting to be helped (I was ear hustling).

Anyhow, don't be discouraged by this review. If sat at a table, no worries, great attentive service. The bar on the other hand... its a no go. 

The pork chop, beef carpaccio, and the fried banana is my favorite dishes.
author: Kaylie P.

description: My go-to restaurant for Vietnamese "street" food and bun bo hue.  The wait staff is friendly, capable and they have excellent beers on top (read: Fin du Monde).
author: Jenn L.

description: Pleasant ambience and friendly staff but very disappointing food - all of our dishes were extremely sugary and it's much more of an Asian fusion than Vietnamese
author: Róisín D.

description: Service was not great, the waitress forgot two of the items we requested (hot sauce and my husband's sake).  Overpriced Vietnamese, the waiter recommended the Filet Mignon but it basically was a plate of French fries hiding the limited filet in the dish.  Cute décor.
author: Alicia G.

description: My bf took me here on a date on a Thursday night and it wasn't too busy. We ordered a  couple appetizers (the shrimp spring rolls and the pork belly served in little steamed buns). Both were pretty good. For my entree, I ordered the fish clay pot (thanks to other yelp reviews) and was not disappointed. Service was good and the food was tasty. They also have a nice selection of beers! Bonus points for its location on Polk Street!
author: Leana L.

description:
I was on a mission for a rice noodle bowl and some five spice chicken (some comfort food) last Friday night. I wasn't feeling good and that usually fixes me up. So when I found this place (off Yelp) I was excited to give it a try. Plus it was close to me (location) at the time. 
First off the decor was very unique with the chandelier being a carrying pole (Yoke) filled with illuminated, clear glass bottles. The "living" wall with different colored/varieties of moss in a very organic pattern. Love the rolling ladder at the bar. And the bathrooms were clean and that sink..so cool! Needless to say I thought the place had great feng shui. 
Secondly, I was greeted timely and with a smile (I can't tell you how many times I see employees "put out" by simply doing their job). The bartender was knowledgeable about their cocktails (and every liquor/spirit/sake they carried) and was quick to produce them. 
But then...oh boy, my food came :) Smelled just as I was imagining it to be. Good size portion of the nouc cham and the 5-spice chicken was moist and flavorful. Egg rolls that came with it (had to order those extra, but so worth the $2) were rolled tight and were flaky not chewy, like so many are at other places! 
Overall I give this place SIX stars for doing everything right. Nice job guys/girls, I will be back!
author: Andrew B.

description: This place is amazing!  We stumbled in here and were greeted with genuinely great and kind service and wonderful, personal food.  We really enjoyed everything we ate, and the prices were low.  Can't wait to return!
author: Matt S.

description:
Very much enjoyed my first dinner here this past Wednesday.  I absolutely love the décor and vibe of this restaurant.  The walls, bar, lighting and Moby like tunes playing in the background all make for a great mood to dine on tasty Vietnamese food.  The crispy rolls were a great appetizer and I also tried the shaking beef as an entrée which comes on a bed of greens and no rice or noodles (exactly the dish I was in the mood for, it was quite nice).  

The service was fantastic, around when you needed them but never pressured us through our meal.  I will definitely be back, and definitely recommend.  My one suggestion for improvement, this restaurant seems too nice to be using paper napkins.  I noticed that at least one person from each table around us, (including me at my table, oops!) dropped their paper napkin from their lap at one point.  The paper ones feel way to "fast foody" for a place like this.
author: Janelle C.

description: It's one of the better restaurants on Polk. I went for a small birthday dinner for 8 people and they were super nice and accommodating. The place is small, but perfect if you want to have a nice, modern place to eat then go out to the bars on Polk.
author: Tessa C.

description:
We love the spicy soju martini! And their cocktail lists are delicious'
Food is fresh and affordable. Highly recommend !
author: Katie E.

description: Had a birthday party for the wife here a few days ago. The Staff was teriffic, the kitchen kept the rest of the tables running as our party of 10 was served without delay. Very impressive and very responsive. Just an e-mail set the plans up and they were ready for us as we arrived.
author: Brendan M.

description: Great flavors, great atmosphere, awesome staff! I definitely recommend this place if you're looking for your fix of some hearty asian noodles. Everything tasted super fresh. I can't vouch for their brunch food because I didn't try it but I'm sure it's also delicious. Don't hesitate to give this place a try. Only downside was that they were understaffed and it took a long time to get our check.
author: Isabel B.

description:
That shaking beef.... I could eat just that, but everything else is yummy too. Except spring rolls are nothing special, better spring rolls at Zadin in the Castro. Pricey and worth it. Unique decor, really pretty. That will be my new go to restaurant in Pac Heights / Nob Hill. And go with friends so you can order and try lots of things on the menu. On par with Out the Door on Bush/Fillmore and Zadin. Yummy!!!

Although they need to hire another server, there were only 3 people working the front, tables and bar tending on Saturday night. Don't go in a big hurry. But really awesome, highly recommend.
author: Michelle G.

description:
I really wasn't that impressed by this place. This feels very much like a dressed up vietnamese restaurant. Everything in the restaurant is black and they played lounge-y type music. I don't recall a dj :).

I had the beef noodle soup and the veggie rolls to start. The beef noodle soup was alright, it wasn't super hot. It was alright. It wasn't terrible impressed. A couple of friends ordered the veggie stir fry, they definitely weren't raving about it. Was expecting more but just got your standard vietnamese food experience with a little more decor than what you'd find normally at a place in the richmond.
author: Michael S.

description: Delicous!! Fish claypot, street food calamari, green beans, shaken beef, veg spring roll!!! Sparkling lychee and mango drinks were yummy too!
author: Chris V.

description: The food is good but takes forever. The service is horrible and the attitude of the guy who served us was TERRIBLE! Not even gave us water after sitting there for 30 mins. We waved to him for couple times trying to order but he ignored us. Overall, the food is good but the service ruins everything. Never go there again!
author: Evelyn L.

description:
Went here for dinner on a Thursday night. We had a big party, about 10 of us. The space is small so our group took up most of the space in front of the restaurant. 

We shared the rolls sampler = $21 and it was about one roll cut in half of each roll. The rolls were ok, we managed to get everyone one half roll. 

We also ordered garlic noodles and the pork belly buns as appetizers. both were delish but the serving size of these as appetizers was not enough for a group our size. The pork belly buns wee 3 for one order so we couldn't share this among 10 ppl. the garlic noodles looks like it would be good to split between 2 ppl at max? 

As for drinks, I got the elderflower martini which was light and crisp! I really liked it. I think all their soju/sake martinis are worth getting for all the unique flavors.

For my entree I got the basa fish clay pot with a side of brown rice. The fish was very flavorful and I added the extra chilis which were served on the side so that gave it an extra kick. Would really recommend getting a side of rice as the sauce the fish is simmering in is great to mix up in your rice bowl. 

Overall our group split bill came to about $40 -$50 per person and that incl. tip and tax. I think its a bit expensive for vietnamese food but it has a nice ambiance and it's a nicer vietnamese place to take a date right on polk st.
author: Christine W.

description:
I been here several times, however, i never get to write a review about this restaurant. This is my first review in all time. =) Anyway, i really like the environment of this restaurant. the layout is cute and very modern.  Importantly very clean so is a plus. 

As for foods, Most of the stuff i orders was good, however is not a typical vietnamese foods I thought it would be.  The services is very friendly and very welcoming when I walk in. There is small selections of cocktails but the one so far i like is blue geisha, is light and somewhat fruity cuz of the lychee.
