In addition, they have lots of different types of drinks for people that doesn't like cocktails as much. 

I would definitely come back to try other dishes that they have and also their cocktails!
author: Lala B.

description: Being just north of Little Saigon, Co Nam really should step up the game.  I was more than slightly resentful that I was paying $13 for a "grilled pork noodle bowl" when I could have had a better, cheaper version of "Bun Thit Nuong" at several other places within blocks of Co Nam  I know, I am the one who went there, but ambiance shouldn't cost more than good, quality food.  What also peeved me, is that i almost choked on the grilled pork.  It was in much larger pieces than most Vietnamese places, much tougher and had a lot more hard fatty pieces. Not cool.  Normally I eat all the pork and then work on the vermicelli, but this time I ate all the vermicelli and left the pork, and I never leave pork.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
came here with my friend, because HOPR was busy so we ended up walking over here. 

as soon as we walked in, they said 'sit where ever you want..' (if I am going to pay that much for Vietnamese food, you better have your seating arrangement correct) we sat for a 10 mins, and still NO MENU we ended up just grabbing it ourselves. (i think they should open up shop in the TL they will feel right at home)

we ordered: 

Bo tai chanh: platted very nice, but the flavor was alright, need more onions and basil. 

clay pot catfish: this was pretty delish cat fish was soft and sauce was perfect. 

bun thit nuong: save your money. 

Overall? for the price? service? food? Save you money, because Vietnamese food itself is very inexpensive and to pay this much for weak service and for food that is hit or miss, it's just not worth it.
author: Zane T.

description: Tried this new Vietnamese place on Polk and I was pleasantly surprised.  The place was nicely decorated and service was good.  I only tried 1 dish since it was lunch.  The bun Rieu was very authentic and tasty.  It's the best I've had at a restaurant.  My husband had a cold noodle salad with grilled pork and that was tasty too.
author: Christina S.

description: Wow! Trendy but simple interior welcomes you.  The dishes pop with incredible flavors.  The shaken beef is the most delicious I've had, with lean cuts of filet mignon and a simple DIY lime pepper sauce.  The pho used the same lean filet cuts, and is great on western palates (they steer clear of tendon and tripe). The Brussels sprout chips were a great surprise.  The papaya salad wasn't as spicy as I'm used to but very tasty.  Everything was clean, complex and delicious.
author: Dan F.

description:
Came here for Sunday brunch. 
BEST FRENCH TOAST EVER! 
Their bloody Mary is really good too. Staff was nice and attentive. Overall great experience and food. I'm glad the had display food on the table out front to draw us in.. Definitely will be back!!
author: Mia S.

description:
Came here on a Tuesday night. Called ahead and was promptly seated. Food is good. We had the shaken beef and the lemongrass chicken. My main food gripe was that my shaken beef was room temp by the time it got to me. Normally I would have sent something like this back to the kitchen but that would have meant I would be left wondering if I would ever get my dish back. Service was horrendous and I really don't know what was the cause of it. Lack of anticipation of how busy it was going to be? Staffing issues? The poor lone waitress and lone bartender were busting their butts and serving the entire restaurant. It's not a huge establishment but we waited forever to place our order. And to get our drinks. And to get our food. I asked for the bill right away not knowing when I'd be able to flag the waitress down. No one ever checked on us during our meal. The hubI would have gladly ordered more drinks. The waitress was obviously very stressed and short with each interaction she had with us. 

Oh, and if you have kids, leave them at home. The place isn't very kid friendly. In other words, no high chairs. Waitress looked at us like we were idiots when we asked for one for our daughter. 

Place definitely has potential but I don't know that I'll be going back any time soon.
author: Denise B.

description:
Solid spot. I was craving some Vietnamese food, but Out the Door was booked solid. 

Seating is limited so they stagger the tables, so best to reserve a spot before you head over. 

They have some interesting cocktails - I had the Co Nam, which had some egg white in it and some other stuff I couldn't figure out. Pretty good though and stiff. 

For dinner, I had the Beef Vermicelli bowl, and the wife had some mixed veggie plate. Both were pretty solid.
author: Count C.

description:
The price is not right, in this case. The food we had was just good (the bun bo hue) and OK (the basa claypot,taste was fine but fish was too soft and gooey), but the price would suggest better than good vietnamese. $15 for a bowl of bb hue, when i can get a bowl that's just as good at Pho Vietnam just down the street for about half that. So you know, we eat Vietnamese frequently and last year went to the source. So we know street vs upper end, etc. The issue with Co Nam now is it's caught in the middle. If they want to nail the mid-scale then the food needs to be both better than and more creative than the very high quality traditional (and cheaper)  fare you can get at Pagolac, Pho Vietnam (esp the soups), and Golden Star (killer 5-spice chicken, etc). 

To calibrate, if the price was cheaper and the food the same, they'd get 3 stars.
author: Eric T.

description: Good food, but the service is lacking. Our waiter disappeared for quite some time after taking our drink order, and we eventually had to waive someone else down to take our meal order. Based on the disorganization of the service, I'd be surprised if our experience was an isolated incident. I'd find it hard to justify the prices based on the experience.
author: Kate T.

description:
I crave the poached shrimp spring rolls all the time!! Not only is is so fresh but savory. the pork belly this evening just melted on my palate! 
My BF always gets the lemongrass basil chicken entree, soooooo good! & I've mixed it up with the clay pots but my go tibia the rice bowl with the chicken or pork. The service is always terrific and attentive! Its our neighborhood gem!
author: Lauren C.

description: Great option on Polk, but a little pricey and slow for my liking. Food is decent though -- would recommend the filet with potatoes, the lemongrass beef noodle bowl, and one of the claypots. Their cocktails are pretty good, particularly the Spicy Cocktail.
author: Shirley L.

description: Was so disappointed in dinner last night at Co Nam. Used to be a favorite go to restaurant. But last two times, I have taken friends or family and the food has been served cold and way over seasoned. The people that I have taken were not impressed. What a shame. None of us will be returning. I was hoping since I haven't been in awhile, the last visit was just a fluke. But same issues. Food not served hot. And too salty and over seasoned. Friendly waitress though. It's too bad.
author: Alisa H.

description:
I noticed this spot pop up a few weeks ago in my hood and was curious to check it out.  Finally went for dinner with a couple friends and.....I hate to say it but there's just something off about it!  

We tried a couple apps which were mediocre as well as the veggie vermicelli and the filet mignon entrees and they were both very average.  The vermicelli was okay, not amazing and the filet dish was served cold, which was a let down.  

The place was pretty dead when we showed up around 7ish and picked up a bit in the cpl hours we were there. This place has potential as far as location and ambiance goes, but definitely room for improvement on the food.
author: Gohar J.

description:
Nice decor.  Took over the space from an Indian restaurant that didn't do well.  Walked by many times but finally decided to give it a try.  Just ordered a beer and a variety of appetizers.  Got the grilled mussels, sugar cane shrimp, pork belly, garlic noodles, fried shrimp pops and chicken wings.  Went during Happy Hour and got the beer for $4 a glass and 25% off the appetizers.  Forgot to redeem a free check-in deal for free iced tea.  Next time.  

The food was pretty good; not perfect but went well with the beer (an IPA).  I could nit pick but not point doing that. Each of the appetizers could have been better but we (my GF and I) finished off everything, so it obviously wasn't that bad.  Very large beer/wine selection not available elsewhere on the street.  Not cheap but a good alternative to some of the other less interesting restaurants & drinking joints currently on Polk.

Neglected to try their Bun Bo Hue.  Will have to try that next time when I collect the free iced tea.
author: Martin C.

description:
I love Co Nam for a bunch of reasons. 

First is the beer. While they only have 20 or so beers available, the ones that they do have are delicious. La Fin Du Monde and Coronado Idiot are two of my favorites. They also have lighter fair like Asahi if you're not feeling super adventurous. On top of that, the staff is super generous in giving out samples of the beer. Awesome. 

Second's the food. Love the Spicy Devil Wings. Love the Shaken Beef. Love the Basa Fish Clay Pot. These guys have really delicious, well balanced dishes, with interesting flavors. 

Finally this place has a great vibe. From the people that work here to the decor, I like how Co Nam feels.
author: Mike P.

description: Cute small restaurant catering to younger crowd. Good food. Food is better down the street at Aux Delices.
author: Charles C.

description: Nothing to write home about, food okay, service okay. but do you really want to pay $65.00 for a vermacceili bowl, dish of shaken beef and a coffee. I don't! when there are so many other options in this city.
author: Susan S.

description: Nice ambiance and setting. Food is good but I'd say this is more trendy and fusion than authentic. The higher price point is basically because of the ambiance. If you're really against hole in the wall restaurants (that are cheap and semi-dirty), then you should def check this place out.
author: Diana Y.

description: Love the coffee. Very full flavored, but not too sweet. The wings and filet mignon with fries were good.
author: Doris H.

description:
My wife were walking by this place before it opened, and we were very excited to give it a try. 

Unfortunately, this place was extremely mediocre. The pan seared Basa turned out to be a deep fried piece of fish covered with a thick tomato and onion topping that had the flavor of frank and beans.  The pork spring roll starter - meh - nothing out of the ordinary except the lettuce hanging out and the scarcity of meat. I've had better at the fast food joint on 4th street. The rice crepe starter had a piece of thick, rubbery, and nearly flavorless pork that had the consistency of Spam in it. Disappointing.

The desert - banana cake - was pretty awful.  It was bland, stringy, with almost no banana flavor.  Our waitress attempted to warn us, but we didn't quite pick up on her discrete & professional subtlety.

Even the rice was lacking. What saved our meal was a surprising side of bok choy and mushrooms.

Honestly, Conam seemed like an attempt at western influenced Vietnamese gone wrong.  I am sure the owners will disagree and suggest this is truly authentic. 

My wife and I eat a lot of "ese" with a preference for Vietnamese. We frequent the best in the Tenderloin and seek out great Vietnamese in Sacramento and San Jose whenever we pass through.

San Francisco is blessed an abundance of great Vietnamese restaurants. Even the cheap eat Vietnamese restaurants blow this one away.

Try the lemon grass chicken here:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/my-canh-san-francisco

Try the clay pot seafood here:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/pho-vung-tau-san-francisco

Try the shaking beef here:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/sais-restaurant-san-francisco

Try the 7 kinds of beef here:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/anh-hong-restaurant-san-francisco

Try the crab rolls here:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/bodega-bistro-san-francisco-2

Try the banh hoi here:
http://www.yelp.com/biz/pagolac-san-francisco

You can taste the authentic family-style skill at these restaurants.  This is what rustic Vietnamese should be. Very disappointing this is not what is happening at Conam.  

For the sake of these entrepreneurs, I hope this is early misfires.  I'd strongly suggest digging deep and figuring out how to get REALLY rustic. Kudos on a nice-looking restaurant. Now you have to deliver on the promise.
author: Ken P.

description: One of my go to spots in the city. Basa fish clay pot is the best thing on the menu. It's surprisingly large for a small looking storefront so it's not hard to get a table. There's also the option of eating at the bar.
author: Carly K.

description:
Was surprisingly impressed with this place!! Initially, I was a bit skeptical about the restaurant because of the prices and the seemingly pretentious food concepts since I've had amazing Vietnamese food for much cheaper at many other establishments. However, my friends and I still decided to give this place a chance after reading some of the wonderful reviews on Yelp. The place was already so packed around 6pm, but we still managed to get a table since we only had 3 people.

Loved the contemporary interior design and artistic touches. The modernized decor, dark walls, and dim lighting evoked this sexy, relaxing atmosphere. It made me want to make out with the food & stuff....just kidding. 

Here's what we ordered:

- Grilled Pork Spring Rolls $8
- Sauteed Filet Mignon $16
- Braised Basa Fish Claypot $14
- Grilled Pork Noodle Bowl $13

I enjoyed all the dishes very much. Although different, I was able to taste the creativity and authenticity in each dish. The tantalizing, unique flavors, tastes, and spices incorporated into each selected entree & appetizer greatly appealed to us. I assure you that you'll enjoy almost every bite here. I must say that my favorite of the night was the Grilled Pork Noodle Bowl. I liked everything else very much, but I was craving noodles for the longest time, and this truly pleased me.

Service was simply awesome! The owner even came over to introduce himself and talk to us for awhile. A driven young man with such great passion and a creative soul. I wish this restaurant all the best as it continues to thrive!!
author: Juliet Rachel C.

description:
I was walking by on my way to another vietnamese restaurant with cafeteria style decor and MSG every dish when I saw this gem.  

I have been to Vietnam and this was better than any restaurant I went to in the entire country.  Every dish was delicate while still generous in portion and utterly delicious.  The street food was a pleasant surprise on a stick.  There was nothing I wouldn't order again.

The decor was both modern and appropriate for a Vietnamese restaurant and evoked the best of my trip to Vietnam.

I highly recommend this place!
author: M S.

description: The food tasted really fresh and healthy. The hot and sour soup was tasty and had many pieces of Baja fish. The Banh Mi sanwich was very tasty. The Banh Mi sanwich bread was great and the meat in it was tender and juicy. The Spring roll was packed with veggies and tasted like a garden. The calamari skewers were grilled to perfection. I love the food there.
author: Ananya P.

description: Chicken clay pot...yum! Veggies were really fresh. In general, the restaurant was small but well-decorate and quiet. Will be back to this spot soon.
author: Janelle G.

description: Fun spot.  The wicked buns, despite 3 small ones, were delicious.  The food was vibrant in color, and fantastic in flavor.  The server was cute and sweet, too.
author: Matt D.

description: We went on a Friday night and had no problem getting a table. The food was amazing! The food was not authentic, more Vietnamese inspired. I can get down with it though. The pork roll was great, especially with the amazing dipping sauce. I got the noodle bowl, which was big, full of flavor, but still light. My bf got the red hook, which I definitely stole some of. It was fantastic!
author: Kelsey S.

description:
This place has reasonable prices and delicious food! The pork sticky buns app was only $9 and was enough for a full meal, and the sugar cane shrimp rolls were a great starter. Date got the chicken clay pot, which was also delicious.

Wait staff was super friendly and attentive. Would definitely recommend. I will be back for those rolls!!
author: Charlie D.

description: Love this place! The garlic noodles are delicious and they have an amazing selection of wines and beers. Great date spot. This is our go-to restaurant!
author: Anish B.

description: Good spot for a date night, as it's easy to get into and conveniently located on Polk. But the food is average at best and slightly overpriced for what it is!
author: Claire S.

description:
This is the third restaurant that's appeared in this location in as many years. I liked each of the other two quite a lot, but for some reason I guess they couldn't make it work. I guess it's kind of a tough location, since it's not quite by all the dive bars on Lower Polk, but neither is it near all the trendy bars on Upper Polk.

Whatever the case, when I saw the sign for "Rustic Vietnamese" food go up, I was excited to try it out.


THE GOOD

- My pulled pork vermicelli was, overall, quite delicious. I'd get it again, but the menu had enough intriguing stuff on it that I'd probably explore further the next time I come here.

- Following up on the previous point: I'd come here again.

- Classy ambiance. Quiet enough to talk. Would be a great place for small groups to dine.

- Service was very attentive and, honestly, kind of adorable. And as I type that, I realize just how condescending it sounds, so let me explain. I'm just saying that it was kind of clear that this place opened really recently and the staff was still getting the hang of things--in a totally forgivable and friendly kind of way.

- Seriously, I was totally rooting for my waiter. Again, I know, with the condescension. Sorry. Sorry sorry sorry.


THE LESS GOOD

- I can't call it bad, because I liked it well enough to finish it, but the dessert soup is probably not something I would get again. That said, I have never had a dessert soup before, and therefore have nothing against which to judge it. It's entirely possible that I just don't like dessert soup. It was interesting. And in fact, I take back what I said earlier. If I were in the right mood, I could see myself getting it again.

- My pulled pork was not, as far as I could tell, pulled. This may be a culinary misapprehension on my part. But it seemed like more or less regular pork to me. The point is somewhat moot because It tasted great, but it was a surprise.

- Also, one of the pieces of pork was pretty tough.

- The price is not quite right. My meal (pulled pork vermicelli entree and dessert soup) came up to $25 (including tip). I would have been happier with something closer to $20. (Admittedly, my entree was one of the more expensive ones.)

- Try to sit away from the entrance. Otherwise, if it's a chilly night (i.e., every night in SF), you're gonna get at least one or two unpleasant blasts.


IN SUMMARY

Solid stuff. I was perhaps a little lenient in the star rating because this place *just* opened, but I do hope they manage to stick around.
author: Greg P.

description: Delicious.  My friend had her bachelorette party dinner here and they were so accommodating to our group.  We ate so many different things - but my favorite was the steak and fries.  It was so good - I am still thinking about it months later.
author: Autumn B.

description:
Super excited to have Co Nam join the Polk St scene. We live nearby, and had passed by a few times, always saying "we should go there"... And I'm glad we finally did. 

It's nice to have a place with a sense of ambience and decor among all the hole in the wall dives on Polk. That being said, it didn't feel to be trying to hard or pretentious; it was just comfortable. 

We came in after 9pm on a Friday, and the place was almost at capacity. We were offered a table or the bar and chose the bar. My only gripe about the entire experience is at the bar, there was a strong residual beer smell, but we got used to it. (Some candles would probably help!)

Cocktails, all made with soju, were carefully and cleverly crafted. Over the course of the meal, we tried the Street Peddler and the Cucumber Martini (worked well together: heat and cooling), and the Elderflower Martini (sweet... We had it for dessert).

We had the poached shrimp spring rolls (there is something magical in that peanut sauce, and I don't even care if it's just sugar), the poached calamari salad (a little vinegary, but appropriate for the dish), a street daily selection of calamari, shishito peppers, beans, green onions, and ponzu sauce (just... Yum), and finally, the basil lemongrass chicken (simple but powerful flavors). They missed our order for the spring rolls, but when they realized, promptly comped them and had the plate out in minutes.

That would have been enough... it was truly a delightful experience... and then we were brought beignets to sample. I hope they end up on the menu, because I'm still thinking about them. 

Food = 5 stars. Service = 5... And maybe an extra half. We'll definitely be back!
author: Jasmine F.

description: Stopped here for breakfast on a Sunday. Great host and delicious food. Best Vietnamese coffee outside of east Asia! Try it!
author: Mike W.

description: This place is amazing. Great service and great food. The steak with French fries is to die for and the wings, pork belly, and garlic noodles are amazing! We eat here at least once a week and are never disappointed.
author: jeff d.

description:
Made a reservation on Opentable, let them know we were a little early, no problem they said... 

Hubs and I ordered two appetizers (chicken heart skewers and garlic noodles) and two entrees (claypot medly and lemon basil chicken) to share. Appetizers were good, heart skewers were juicy and garlic noodles had enough flavor.  Entrees were a little too savory for our taste, but something worth trying again.  

But the service, ick. Where do I start? Our water glasses were constantly empty.  Waiters seemed angry/irritated when we asked for refill.  Even though the tables on either side of us were seated after us, they finished their meals and dessert way before we even got our dessert menu.  I really tried to give dessert a chance, waiter cleared our table, asked if we  wanted to see the dessert menu, and I said sure.  After waiting 15 minutes for a dessert and watching our neighboring tables finish theirs, we had enough and asked for the check.  Took forever for us to get that too.

And to top it off, when I got home, I got an email from Opentable that they canceled my reservation because I was a no-show.
author: Irene D.

description:
Delicious and great service.  

They do get busy but when they get to you they are very consistently attentive.

We were there for Lunch and they offer up the lunch menu but also give you a look at the dinner menu in case you want to expan beyond the lunch.

The Geso Fries appetizer were excellent!  We ordered two rounds.

Will definitely be back!
author: Martin S.

description:
Cute little place on Polk. Need more of these places on Polk.  You can tell they spent a good amount of effort, time, and money on how they designed the space.  Had a chat with the owner and he said he's an architect/designer by training....makes sense.

Agree with other folks that the prices are a bit high (they really should consider dropping prices by a few bucks.  The rent can't be THAT high in that part of Polk)

But on to how the food tastes....

1. Grilled mussels - 4 starts. Nicely grilled and dipping sauce had a good sweet, tangy balance.

2. Pork belly - 3 starts - decent but not memorable compared to the other dishes

3. Bptyass clay pot fish - 4 stars - very good flavors. Fish was fresh and the caramelization/spices were perfect. Without s doubt will order this again.

Nice job!

Some recommendations to the owners:

The design is very welcoming but your service though not bad could be more personal.  I have dined here a few times and though I never felt rushed, your service staff should be more on the ball about reading when a patron is ready to go (please bring the check) vs. they want to stick around and enjoy the ambiance a bit more, allow themselves to digest so recommend a nice after dinner cocktail, port, drink...whatever.  Bring them more water as they sit.  This is especially important if the restaurant is not busy.  After all if you rush them out before they are ready you lose in two ways...1. patron feels rushed and is annoyed 2. restaurant looks empty and new patrons may not trust dining at a place that looks empty.
author: Lev E.

description:
Solid, new entrant into the neighborhood and a much-appreciated one, at that. I'm a fan of nuanced, light, fresh Southeast Asian food and Conam delivers. The portions are small, but the flavors are manifold and delightful - case in point is the Omely wrap. You get about six lettuce cups, savory fish paste (was this anchovy?), and a selection of other fillings (dried shrimp, ginger, chili bird pepper, among the things I remember) that you put together - the lettuce cups are small and soon gone, but each bite is hauntingly salty, spicy, slightly sweet, with textural contrast provided by the smooth paste on the crispy lettuce.

The entrees are equally strong, with the house special one day (I think it was seafood soup with vermicelli noodles) making a strong aromatic entrance before it reached our table, causing us to salivate before we dug into the rich, meaty, hearty stew. I've also enjoyed the braised basa clay pot, finding the balance of caramelized sauce and thick chunks of basa to be a nice foil for rice or your other starch of choice.

I wasn't a huge fan of the desserts here, not ever having gotten onto the dessert soup train, even as a young girl in Beijing where such a thing is de rigueur. Conam also offered a banana-based dessert that looked tasty, as well as an organic yogurt with blueberries option, so the dessert here may be fabulous. For me, it wasn't ideal, so I'm giving them 4 instead of 5 stars.

I urge you to try this place and form your own opinion - the ambiance is calming, the house music is usually house music, and the decor is evocative of Vietnam. You'll experience some flavor explosions and walk away feeling a bit happier - promise :).
author: Annie M.

description:
Pretty good food that's a refreshing change from some of the other Vietnamese options in the neighborhood. Cordon Bleu has lost a little in terms of quality over the past few years. I'm not the only one thinking this, several of my friends thought so, too. Pho Vietnam is good if you want a quick bowl of pho or some OK bun, but it's just basic (spartan) dining. 

So when Co Nam opened their doors I was really excited to have something "nicer" (but not froo-froo) in the hood without walking all the way down to Aux Delices. The food here definitely could give Aux Delices a run for their money if Co Nam's dishes were priced a little more modestly. Don't get me wrong, I like this place. The food is good, but it's not on the level of Slanted Door.....so we shouldn't be paying Slanted Door prices.

That said, the shrimp ball appetizers and 5 spice chicken are both really good. The GF gets the clay pot entree every time so it's gotta be OK. I had the basa before and it reminded me of a weaker catfish courtbouillon. Not bad, but not as good as what I've had (and made at home).

Overall, give this place a whirl. It's something this stretch of Polk desperately needs (dear god no more cheapo take-out-oriented places).
author: Richard H.

description:
I wouldn't expect to find a Vietnamese restaurant in this cool and hip neighborhood. Hell I didn't even know there was one here.
But I have to say, Co Nam is now my favorite Vietnamese place in the city. I've been on this quest to find real Vietnamese food in SF and I am so glad this day finally happened. My decision to go over my dining out budget for the month paid off big time !
I went with my 2 roommates and we were all very happy with everything.
We started with the Bo La Lot - a street food that is very typical in Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam. Man the sauce...THE SAUCE. My friend was like "Did you try to make that sauce the other day at home?" and I'm like "I only tried to make it cuz I couldn't find that anywhere here in sf. If I knew Co Nam sells it, I would've just bought it here"
Next we tried the 3 soups: Sweet & Sour, Bun Rieu, and Bun Bo Hue.
All 3 of them taste exactly like how it;s supposed to. I feel so homesick eating Co Nam's food.
The Basa FIsh in the claypot could be a little saltier and a little less sweet. But overall, I left the restaurant very satisfied. I even forgot I have a paper to write for school for a minute.
My roommates and I are planning to make Co Nam our Tuesday go-to comfort homey place from now on.
author: Alan T.

description: This place is beautiful and the food is delicious. I've been here over 10 times and it never disappoints me. The waiter Amrita is very helpful and just a great host. I love the decorations and think it's a hidden jem on Polk st. I have tried a lot of the dishes and my favorite are their brussel sprouts, stir fry vegetables, steak salad, vegetable spring rolls and can't remember the name of the others but they are all uniquely flavored. Big plus for this place.
author: parisa e.

description: I initially thought it was a little expensive, but then found that the portion was huge (I could split it up into two meals). Very flavorful and good meat.
author: Kira G.

description: I went here for dinner and it was a really enjoyable experience. The staff were very friendly and made great suggestions. We got a noodle bowl and a clay pot and they were tasty, as was the papaya salad. The staff were super helpful and when we had to get going, they were quick to get the check. They forgot to take off some of the cost for what we got during happy hour, but were very quick and pleasant to change it to the correct amount, which was helpful because the dinner was not cheap. It wasn't the best food I've had, but it was certainly a positive experience.
author: Rachel S.

description: Very good Vietnamese style food and a decent wine/beer selection to boot!   After dining you should check out Bob's Donut Shop down the street.  I highly recommend the Apple Fritter. Your life will never be the same!
author: Pat D.

description:
What a great surprise!

We had:
Braised Silver Fish - think salty fish jerky over rice with a hint of spiciness. A delicious unconventional way to start off a meal.
Pan-Seared Basa - incredibly tasty with a good amount of spicy peppers. Texture was almost pork-belly like, delicious. 
Chicken Clay Pot - my entree, when I first saw it I was a little disappointed, it looked like a chicken pot pie without the crust and gravy. Once I dug in, I could really appreciate it, beautifully aromatic. Tasted like the whole dish had been steamed in a lemongrass mushroom broth. I will definitely order it again. Got especially delicious with the hot sauce that was served (the one without the chili flakes was my preference)
French-Vietnamese Yogurt with raspberries - THE HIGHLIGHT - delicious, sweet, incredibly locious. I could have eaten ten servings, no joke.

The servers were very nice. The owner came by and asked us how we liked the meal, the server gave great recommendations and was very ... cheery. The drink, cucumber martini, was just okay. Out of 8 cocktails, they only had materials for two.

The place is a bit expensive, definitely for Vietnamese food. Nevertheless, that yogurt was such a showstopper I have to go back.
author: Cristina M.

description:
First of all I have to say that I am happy there is a new "cool" place in the neighborhood... We have many food options in the area some of them great but not many places where you would bring a first date... I mean a cozy, fancy-funny place.
Do not get me wrong, the place is just fine but I really like the atmosphere.
From my experience food is pretty good, I guess it really depends on what you order. We had the noodle bowl, calamari salad and omelet rolls plus fried banana for dessert. All these were very decent dishes so I am fine with the food.
Service could be better of course but we can't forget this is a new place and they are still probably adjusting things plus it is pretty busy all the time.
I definitely will come back and have a second round!!
author: Mario B.

description: Fantastic food and polite staff, but the slowest service I've experienced in the city. We were a group of 6 and it took ~15 mins to order drinks, a further 10 mins to receive them and ~1 hour to get our food. We tried to hurry the process as much as possible throughout and still had to take the check to the bar to clear it in order to not miss a show. Took almost 2 hrs to finish what should have been a 1 hr quick dinner. I'd love to get takeout from here, but wouldn't come back for dinner.
author: Rodrigo D.

description:
I was skeptical of Co Nam when I first heard about it because I don't believe in "fancy" Vietnamese food. After our meal, I was very pleasantly surprised. It's definitely not authentic but the food is delicious and the flavors are a good representation of the more modern and "new" feel that the restaurant seems to be going for. My group ordered the banh mi, spicy chicken wings, sauteed filet mignon, lemongrass beef noodle bowl, and the fish clay pot, all to share. I liked every dish! Balanced flavors that were all unique to each dish, and each dish was a good reinvention of the classic Vietnamese one. Thanks for proving me wrong!

I also have to say that the service was amazing! Not sure what his name is but he was wearing a Niners jersey the night we came in. Great guy who was very personable and made the experience awesome.
author: Brittany L.

description: Food was alright (had the burger), but the service was pretty terrible for brunch. Took them about 20 minutes from when we sat down to collect our drink orders. I read the other reviews, so was disappointed with the service. My friends actually really enjoyed their meals, which is part of the reason why I'm giving them a 3 star instead of a 2 star. I may give them another shot, but it's definitely not squarely in my rotation.
author: Jay G.

description: This place is the best! Their pork belly sliders and to die for! Everybody was so nice to us, they were offering to try new drinks and food. Definitely recommend to everybody.
author: Moni H.

description: Had the fish clay pot and brown rice. Good stuff. Tasted fresh. Nice subtle flavors
author: Tim O.

description: Yumzies. Basa Fish Claypot and Tofu Rice Noodle Bowl. I've had the Claypot before and this time was just as delightful. It's a fair priced family restaurant that's been great to pop into. Maybe I'll see you there next time!
author: Rob L.

description:
No laughing matter.

Conan has perfect timing: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eD1nwe5Esx0

Co Nam needs timing practice: Long lag between sitting and having our order taken. Sporadic water refills. Plates kept coming even though we weren't finished.

Service issues aside there is much to like about the food:

- Sugarcane shrimp rolls include a delicious and unique dash of apple
- Grilled chicken banh mi has plenty of flavor and includes a side of truffle fries
- Clay pot medley contained an impressive amount of chicken, veggies and flavor

Only the street food calamari salad disappointed. Too much dressing. Not enough squid.

House cocktails includes new takes on ginger and martinis. Pairs perfectly. Dim lighting, dark wood accents and abstract art make for a modern and inviting space.

Bathroom sink is awesome. Walking to it you might notice peanut butter and Jim Beam in the kitchen. Perhaps should have ordered something with those.

Everything was reasonably priced (and enough to Replate http://www.replate.org/), and our server was friendly and trying. Just needs to be present more often.

Watch Conan to learn the art of perfect timing.
author: Jason B.

description: This place made my husband and I soooo happy! We stopped by for the banh mi sandwich and it was delicious! I will be dreaming of this sandwich for years to come! The chicken was so good and seasoned to perfection and it came with truffle oil fries! Oh, my! We also tried the clay pot medley and it was so, so, so good!!! We could not stop eating and just looked at each other in amazement when the food was all gone because we had tasted heaven.
author: Jennifer P.

description: they really have a stick up this ass about credit cards and groups. with our party of seven, they would only allow one credit card. annoyed, we gave them some cash and ask them to put the balance on the credit card (for the one couple that didn't have cash). to our astonishment, that wasn't acceptable either-- it had to be either all cash or all credit. who's making these rules?!
author: Aaron F.

description:
I have been here three times and each time was phenomenal. The vibe is hip but relaxed and festive. The decor is intriguing and check out the decor again, is that a living wall? Are those pics of someone's childhood in Vietnam? It's chic and sleek, yet welcoming, if you don't believe me, check it out for yourself.

So that is the vibe and the ambiance but what about the food? To die for, mouthwatering, don't ask me any questions because I am so busy chewing, yum, yum again, great food that is so delish and innovative that you want to take a look at the menu one more time, just to see what it is you are eating and why it tastes so good.

And the staff is efficient and all smiles.
author: Michael M.

description: Confusion galore amongst the people that work here. Slow service and no follow up service. Food is good not great for the $$$
author: Madhusudhan R.

description: This review is for the owner of the store. I normally don't Yelp. This is second review I ever wrote. Went to your restaurant this afternoon, before we went in realized you have a happy hour between 4pm to 6pm. Was there 3:55pm. Asked waitress about the happy hour cocktail, she said the bartender wouldn't  be in till 4pm, then she said just ordered food first, when he comes, you can order the drink. So ordered food. Food came,  taste good, bartender never showed up. So ordered beer. I would give this place at least three or four stars till we got the bill. We were charged full bill, no happy hour discount. The bill was $78.00. Asked the waiter (the waitress left), he said that we ordered on 3:56pm, so won't apply for happy hour. Even explained the reason we ordered , he basically showed no interesting to listen, just said I wasn't here. Don't know. We paid bill, left NO TIPS. This is the first time I ever left nothing for the service. You know, since he won't care, and didn't serve us, why should we left tips! San Francisco is the foodie city, there are tons of good places. The difference is good food and good customer service. The attitude of the serving stuff really could make or break the business. I don't think we will be back there any more.
author: Jian C.

description:
Love the location and the vibe.  The interior design and art work create a chic atmosphere contrasted with pictures of Vietnam.

Tried the five-spice chicken clay-pot, ingredients were very fresh and perfectly spiced.  Service was extremely fast given how crowded the place was.  I'll surely be back, perhaps eat here before the classic polk street pub crawl.
author: Prakhar S.

description:
My boyfriend is Vietnamese, so you can assume I've had great vietnamese food many times. 
This is why I decided to introduce my mom to Vietnamese cuisine. But I should have picked another place!
Co Nam is overpriced restaurant with bland food and terrible service. Another disadvantage- there is no private parking lot. We spent like 20 min looking for a street parking nearby. Oh well, this is San Francisco...

We came for lunch and ordered two dishes: Ban Bo Hue (15$) for me and a rice bowl with grilled five-spice chicken (13$) and an egg roll on the side (2$ extra) for my mom.
It took them quite a while to serve us (around 20-25 min), which is strange because the place was almost empty when we came (around 2:30-3pm). 
My soup came first. I asked it spicy, and they brought me a bunch of red jalapenos on the side. The broth was pretty bland. Pieces of pork had way too much fat, and small amount of meat. I had to leave out the blood thing because it had absolutely NO FLAVOR. Why do you put something like this in the soup? 
The culmination of my disappointment was my mother's rice bowl, which came with pork instead of chicken and a minute egg roll, literally pinky size. When I told them that we asked for a chicken rice bowl, the waiter told us they can grill chicken and bring it on the side. It took them another 10 min, obviously. The amount of chicken they brought was half of the amount of pork my mom had to take out of her rice bowl because she doesn't eat pork. I have to mention, this grilled chicken didn't have a flavor of chicken. I can't really explain what was missing, but something was definitely wrong.
My total was 35 $ (including tax and tips). 

I hate to say it, but dining in Co Nam was quite a miserable experience for us and I will never-ever come back to this place.
author: Natalia P.

description: Stopped in with a couple friends for cocktails and appetizers. We had the Bo La Lot (beef wraps), it's ground beef in betel leaf, pickles, mint, bean sprout, all wrapped in lettuce and served with an anchovy dipping sauce. It's like a Vietnamese sandwich without the bun, a very tasty appetizer. We also had the lettuce chips, I don't remember the Vietnamese name but they are fried Brussel Sprout leaves smothered in garlic and anchovy sauce. A very addicting companion to a cocktail. Cocktails are alittle on the strong side but hey! That's the point sometimes ;) As for service, they were very knowledgable of wines, beers, and cocktails. The decor is very interesting, they have old pictures of Vietnam along the walls. It's about the food and the ambiance, a very good place to go on a date or a special occasion. I don't recommend children, the space is fairly small and intimate. Overall a great experience.
author: France Marie R.

description: Great place for a group of 4-6. Basa fish and the beef carpacio and the pork belly are must gets. To get variety do family style. It's much more fun to try everything.
author: Corey C.

description:
This place is the bomb!!!
The base fish claypot is amazing!!
I've been there three time I've tried something different every time it's always great. The own is cool dude too.
author: Jesus P.

description: The food is amazing!! So flavorful, I loved the Brussels sprout chips, the grilled pork spring rolls, and the garlic noodles! I will definitely be coming back!
author: Gabrielle M.

description:
They get 5 stars because they are NEW and handling the growing pains well. 

I've been there twice.
The sugar cane rolls are amazing. I took an order home for the next days lunch. 
Braised Pork Belly is amazing and a decent portion for what you pay. We had apps and beers. The mains coming out of the kitchen looked great. Enough for two to share as an app.  Definitely going back for main courses soon.
author: Foodie D.

description: This place is simply amazing. Visiting from Miami and went in without any expectations. Food was delicious, staff was very nice, the decor is beautiful and although it was full we were able to have a conversation. Try the Che or the sticky mango rice for dessert. So good!
author: Philip N.

description:
Culinary blasphemy! Ambiance was okay but the food was terrible! For what they are charging, they should be serving something a little better.

Second, the table was dirty, so we cleaned it ourselves, and I was given a dirty plate. I wish I had known how dirty this place is. I would never set foot inside this establishment ever again.

Based on most of the other reviews, it is safe to say though that Co Nam, has very inconsistent dishes from each time you go there.

But if you're a Vietnamese restaurant and you can't make a simple soup, what hope is there for you? I could have boiled my own hot water for free and added sugar, lime and other seasonings to make a better soup than what they delivered to me. 

So 1 star for decoration and I'm being generous by adding another star for customer service.
author: Jake M.

description: This is a cool modern spot, they have great cocktails, and the food is great!  Went on a Friday night, it was pretty crowded and service was a little slow.  All the food looked great, we got the crispy rolls, birds nest, and clay pot Medley, all super delicious and fresh!!
author: Keri K.

description:
Nice design, clean and good food. Pork belly is amazing. The appetizer came out very fast but entrée was slow. The cocktail is great. Kid friendly! And service very nice.
We are looking forward to go back soon.
author: Dear J.

description: Food is not bad but is a bit overpriced for what you get. Plenty more Vietnamese places around the city for much better value. Service was good and the street food menu is interesting.
author: Annika C.

description: Yelpers loved this place so I took my boyfriend for his birthday. I didn't love my food. I had lemongrass chicken, cubed beef, stir fry veggies, and the eggplant carrot dish. The chicken tasted odd, kind of gamey.  The beef was also weird, but had enough seasoning to mask it better. The veggies were meh, and the eggplant and carrot dish was exactly 2 peices of each, served cold and not cooked. Prices were high, portions were small, menu was small. The place is tiny so youre sitting in close quarters here, so youre totally overearing conversations on both sides. I won't go back here.  But the decor was very nice.
author: Y K.

description: I really was pleasantly surprised. I ordered a bowl of bun ba hue that I was expecting to be dumbed down for western tastes but this bowl was legit. Pigs feet and blood and all that good stuff. This was better than a place in sac that supposedly had he best bun Bo hue in town. If I'm in the area I would go back without hesitation.
author: M C.

description: One of my favorite restaurants I've visited in the city! I went again last night and ordered the thai tea martini which I'm a huge fan of but my date was not so he ordered the lychee soju which I would HIGHLY recommend, it's amazing. I wasn't a huge fan of the bahn mi the last time I got it but the clay pot chicken is phenomenal. Last night I ordered the 5 spice chicken rice bowl and loved it. The dressing was just sweet enough and paired very nicely with the spiced chicken. Our waiter was great, he recommended the soju to us and was very friendly and attentive. This place is a must visit.
author: Grace P.

description:
Shaking beef was bomb. Maybe the best I've ever had. Medley claypot was good, but not outstanding. 

Great service. Employees are nice and knowledgeable.

Was empty at 6:45, but filled up and got lively while we were eating. Very pretty decor -- one wall is all plants, dark interior with lots of wood. 

I'd eat here again especially considering Polk street alternatives
author: Alyssa B.

description: I'm a huge fan of Co Nam. We've been several times and it never disappoints. It's one of the more intimate, interestingly decorated restaurants you'll find. Trung & his staff provide excellent service, an ever-changing, thoughtful beer and wine list, and great food. I never miss the shrimp pops, spicy basil wings and Red Hook (think modern Vietnamese fried fish). Recently, they began serving brunch on the weekends. Not only was the brunch fare as good as anything in the neighborhood, there was no waiting. Doh! Why'd I let that secret out?!?!?
author: Corey B.

description:
The lady and I had a good time here today.  Great food and drink, nice clean restaurant, some decent music and polite and attentive service.

Stars of the show were the appetizers.  We had the wicked buns, the garlic herb noodles and some shrimp lollipops from the daily street food menu.  Everything was delicious, and we were regretting not getting more of the noodles and shrimp pops to go.

Entrees were solid as well.  We had the bird's nest and lemongrass chicken.  Presentation of the bird's nest was nice -- it actually looked like one.

Happy hour discounts were a pleasant surprise.  Will be going back!
author: Dom And Jazz C.

description:
For a party of 4 that come in right before they closed, they are the nicest.

DECOR: Very SF chic, warm dark brown colors, with interesting light fixtures. Grass Wall...o_0

APPS: the pork was tasty, the calamari salad was dressed nicely (and the calamari wasn't over cook) and friend springs were OK (i wish there was more veggies and wood ear mushrooms, and less noodles).

ENTREES: Lemon grass Beef vermicelli (could use more lemongrass), Grilled Pork vermicelli (good grilled flavor) and the Braised Chicken (reminds me of the chinese dish Drunken Ginger Chicken, which is always a good thing). The vermicelli with there hot sauce, is really good, if you like spicy. If you don't stay away from their hot sauce, I mean it.

SERVICE: the server was so cute, inside and out. He was very nice and attentive, and had to deal with our late butts, so A+.

Overall, a good meal. I would come back, if I was in the city. I only wish they had Pho...and when we went they didn't have their alcohol license yet, so maybe drinks too next time.
author: Mei L.

description:
Ugh. Beyond disappointed. I love Vietnamese food and was excited to try this place. It looks so chic but leaves the palette wishing for a whole-in-the-wall on Clement Street where they know how to cook.

THE FOOD
We did a bit of sharing, and everything that was put on our table was just plain mediocre. My dish was probably the worst of all -- a chicken claypot with veggies that tasted more like a Lean Cuisine frozen dinner.

THE PRICE
I've seen several other reviewers mention their price point and agree that it is way too expensive for what you get. 

THE BOTTOM LINE
There's far better food in the area. If this place manages to maintain a 4-star rating once it gets up to a couple of hundred reviews, I may give it another try. But I'm doubtful!!
author: Jennifer G.

description: This place was a great find on a busy street. Awesome cocktails, prompt and excellent service, and delicious food. Great atmosphere and good music too. All around fantastic night out!!
author: Steve V.

description: Delicious food, friendly service, and quick! I tried the daily street food...so good, had a spring roll and a salad.  Healthy, filling, and so tasty. Cant wait to come back and try more of the menu...What a better choice for this space than what had been there before!
author: Nilu r.

description:
Wonderful addition to the neighborhood - fantastic service and solid food. A huge upside: really interesting beers on tap that are 1/2 off during happy hour. They are pretty generous about allowing you to sample different draughts before placing your order.

Great for both groups as well as more intimate dinners.
author: sar h.

description: Another new gem in the Polk neighborhood, had the pleasure of dining at the bar with the owner/creative mastermind Trung.  This provided an intimate experience and for us to ask questions about the preparation and nuances of the food.  Modern trendy decor, good drink options.  Omely wrap was interesting make-yourself appetizer, Clay pot was generous, spicy and comforting, and 5-Spice Chicken is a filling but lighter option.  Tried both mango sticky rice and espresso creme brulee for desserts; mango sticky rice was better.
author: Rachel A.

description: This is what I would call very good Viet food. It's worth a visit - and a likely return for me (which says a lot in this town).  I particularly liked the Shaking Beef and the fish clay pot.  Quite delicious.   Food is very nicely presented.  The beer list, both draft and bottle, is excellent.  You should go ahead an eat here!
author: Eric S.

description: Had the bass clay pot and shaken beef started with the pork spring rolls.  Delicious! Cute waiter too very knowledgable about the dishes. Coming back!
author: Kim a.

description: They were really busy when I was there. Even though the food took awhile to come out the staff was super nice and you could tell they were working really hard to serve everyone. I felt bad for the staff having to deal with whiny customers who can't understand things might take some more time if a restaurant is busy and the food they bring out is made to order and not frozen!! I would suggest ordering the burger. And if you like things hot, their ginger cocktail has this very unique, spicy flavor that is worth a try.
author: Bella C.

description: Four of us went to Co Nam on a weeknight and all of us thoroughly enjoyed the food, service and atmosphere.  Very nice host who seated two of us even though we were waiting for two more.  Our server got us drinks while we waited.  This was a nice change from places that won't give you the time of day until your entire party has arrived.  They have a nice selection of beers on tap.  All entrees were really good - clay pot chicken, shaken beef, vermicelli bowl, pork chops.  We were not rushed at all even though the place filled up while we were eating.  We definitely plan to go back.
author: Jennifer A.

description: My boyfriend and I came on a Friday night around 9:30 and got seated right away (awesome!). We wanted to try a bunch of different things instead of just one entree so we ordered some appetizers since happy hour had started at 9:30. We got the shrimp pops (so oily.. I imagined it tasting like a deep fried shrimp dim sum dumpling.. It was nothing like that), garlic herb noodles (ok), and red spicy wings (favorite of the 3 we ordered besides the free thai iced tea and beer). 3 1/2 stars for the food we ordered but 4 stars for service. Our waiter was pretty attentive and was very knowledgable of the menu items. Vermicelli is a must try next time!
author: Michelle B.

description:
We tried this new restaurant for takeout last night since we live around the corner. There was no problem placing our order over the phone, and the food was ready on time. When I arrived (early), the bartender Rafael was experimenting with some new soju-based cocktails and he let me try a few while I was waiting for the food. For a place without a hard liquor license, they can do magic with their own tinctures and concoctions!

The meal was overall very good. We ordered poached shrimp spring rolls, calamari salad, pork belly, and pan-seared basa fish. The spring rolls were hearty and fresh. The calamari salad was a bit light on calamari, but still tasty with other crunchy vegetables. The pork belly was delicious, and the basa fish was very good, particularly the spicy tomato sauce. 

I would definitely eat here again for eat-in or take-out, and I look forward to trying more cocktails! Also, they will be having some lunch specials starting soon which will be great for when I am working from home.

Welcome to the neighborhood Co Nam!
author: Christine G.

description: I've been here a few times.  It seems there is always just one person, during the week, taking orders.  He's terrific at what he does, but sometimes it's hard to get his attention.  The food is good but know it's more like Vietnamese fusion.  Their pork belly dishes are great!.  The soups are satisfying. The street food selections are always interesting.   I will return but go elsewhere for true Vietnamese food.
author: Jane G.

description: Chicken clay pot and good beer selection. Also good decor
author: Mister T.

description:
Fairly new Vietnamese on bustling part of Polk and we really wanted to like this place.   The room is very narrow room and they did a good job making it seem open and bigger.   The service was attentive and good overall.
Our biggest disappointment was the food.   For the shared appetizers the crispy rolls (Imperial?) was presented plain and bland with out any traditional wraps or mint leaves.   The braised mussels were not a hit and only one out of the four in our group would eat it.  The braised silver fish was very unusual (fishy and salty over rice) and 2 out of 4 were ok with it the other 2 wouldn't touch it after the first bite.
The fish claypot was probably the strongest dish going very well with jasmine rice.   The lemon grass beef was ok but nothing special c/w a good clement street vietnamese at half the price.   The filet mignon over 'french fries' the weakest entree.   The amount of filet was small and worst of all it was stir fried to overcooked and topped over semi soggy fries.  Yuck.  
Too bad.  Good location, space, service but they need to rethink the food quality.
author: John P.

description: Love this place. Shaken beef is to die for. I'd say the food and ambiance is fantastic. The cocktails are so-so.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
A great restaurant with a beautiful new design that fits an awkward space perfectly. I hope Conam survives and thrives. My favorites: mussels on the half-shell appetizer and 5-spice chicken entree. Clay pots are fabulous. And the dessert soups are divine (get both and share them). Everything is fresh and perfectly seasoned. 

Everything about the space (down to the bathroom) is simple and beautiful. I love to sit in the restaurant and take in the environment: the collage, the wood, the moss, and the chandelier. Really, it's a lovely place. And the service is attentive, polite, and efficient.
author: Louise L.

description: I hands down love this place! The service is fabulous, always friendly. I haven't had a bad thing off the menu.  Start with the beef carpaccio, trust me you will add a second order. The grilled sugar cane shrimp is yummy and the braised pork belly is to die for. You must complement anything you order with  the garlic herb noodle. I've tried just about everything on the menu. They always offer a few appetizer specials, primarily seafood. Great wine list to complement the meal. I really wished I still lived in the neighborhood as I would probably be there every other night.
author: Deb B.

description: Excellent for lunch with tasty but smaller portions so you don't walk out needing a nap afterwards. The cocktails are also decent and worth a mention. It gets a four vs a five star because the open, airy room is a little cold at lunch time - feels a little too echo-y if there aren't many people and gets too loud when most tables are filled.
author: S C.

description: Very good food in a chic space. Nice waiter. I'd go back in a heartbeat.
author: Sheviche R.

description:
THE GOOD:
 - DECOR: very chic
 - NEW NEW: the place is really new, so while that lasts and it's undiscovered, you get to show your friends how plugged into the city temperature you are =)
 - PORTIONS: The food is well portioned. I hate feeling like I'm wasting food, or feeling hungry afterwards. The staff is also great about describing how big a portion is, if you accidentally order something too big and they sense it. (I speak from experience).

OKAY:
 - the menu selection is the largest, and the old familiars may not be there; however, of everything I've had so far it's been great
 - since the restaurant is new, they may not have worked this out, but it seems like there isn't a dedicated server, they all serve at the same time -- it's a little confusing.

BAD:
  - nothing yet, I'll update if I see something.. I guess you could say space but I like the layout and think it's a plus


RECOMENDED FOR: 
 - dinner dates, catching up with old friends
 - for a date, try eating by the bar, it's spacious, beautiful and I personally found it took the awkward interview feeling away

NOT FOR:
 - families with children
 - people who prefer fast food to good/healthy food
author: Sanjeev D.

description: A terrific addition to the Polk Street scene...I love the banh mi sandwich with truffle fries and the roasted mussel appetizer--soo good!  It took some folks with a solid sense of design to finally banish the Double Rainbow aesthetic, and these folks finally turned the space into something interesting and inviting, with good food to boot.
author: Jennifer F.

description: We're definitely coming back.  It is a bit pricey (for Vietnamese food) but it was worth it.  The staff was very warm and attentive.  Good ambiance and drinks.  We had the 5 spiced chicken banh mi, fish clay pot, beef carpaccio, and one other thing that I can't seem to remember.  However, the sandwich was a star...granted it was priiiicey...but was the best sandwich i had in a loooonng while.  4.5 stars for us!
author: thuy n.

description: Got the 5 spic chicken to-go and it was delicious.  A little pricy but still very good.
author: Ryan S.

description: Amazing! Great atmosphere, wonderful cocktails, trendy music, and fantastic food!
author: Rebecca F.

description:
This clean, inviting, modern looking restaurant is a welcome addition to Polk St.  Based on two trips and sampling a range of different items, there is no doubt that Conam generally turns down the taste and spice to cater to a wider audience.  This is not necessarily bad but it's def helpful to know beforehand.  

The service both times was fantastic - warm, attentive, friendly.

Also, please note this restaurant just opened and they will, without a doubt, make adjustments to the menu and recipes.  If I could cast a vote, I would ask them to go for it - make the food bolder, more authentic
author: David C.

description: Awesome pork spring rolls.  The pork chops were kind of dry.  The pot medley was okay but not for the 16 dollar price tag. Sautéed green beans were pretty good. The service was friendly and helpful. We may have just picked the wrong dishes.
author: Nicole B.

description: A friend and I tried the brunch at Co Nam after walking by a beautifully set table out on the sidewalk showcasing their fritatta and french toast.  We ordered the french omelet and the brioche french toast with berries - both were amazing.  We'll definitely go back - highly recommended, worth every penny!
author: Megan G.

description: This is a bustling little place with terrific food.  The staff was very friendly and attentive.  If all the tables are filled, you can eat at the bar.
author: Jon G.

description: Wow what aamazing food....bahn mi. ..god damn...what a great place...
author: Arjan P.

description: Wednesday night dinner with pork spring rolls, calamari salad and lemon grass beef vermicelli.  Everything is excellent and they have a nice wine/beer list.   A welcome addition to the neighborhood.
author: Corey V.

description: The space is very inviting, warm, and chic. I love the light fixtures made of baskets filled with glass bottles and the plant wall. We shared the grilled pork dish, five spice chicken, grilled pork spring rolls and the wings (a special for the night). Everything was very good; favorite being the wings. You can't go wrong with this place!
author: Linh S.

description: Service was atrocious. Went last night at a not very busy time and it took forever to order, waiter forgot our order and then our food took 45 minutes and it was just appetizers. Food was decent but I will never go back.
author: Virginia R.

description: Fabulous dinner. Everything was great, especially the red hook fish.  Unexpectedly perfectly fried with tons of flavor. Also had the vermicelli bowl with beef which was also very tasty.
author: Julie W.

description: Interesting and tasty food. Service just OK.
author: Mary W.

description:
taking asian food to a new level in SF
which is hard to do since it's such a value based and competitive market
but Co Nam do a good job of offering fine ingredients in a Vietnamese dining experience
not sure if it's a bar or restaurant though, which is hard to accept sometimes when looking to indulge in food alone and cocktails seem to be offered every few minutes
try it once if on Polk and you decide. It will add 20% to your usual asian food bill, but in turn add 50% to your health with the carefully selected ingredients and combinations.
author: Jed K.

description: Great new neighborhood restaurant, upscale but comfortable.  The owner is really hospitable and energetic and the food is delicious!    Great place for a glass of wine and an appetizer at the bar after work.
author: K P.

description: I've seen lots of restaurants come and go in this space.  This one is my favorite so far.  I loved the Bahn Mi and the spring rolls.  I've always loved Unicorn downtown.  The owner has created another winner.  I can't wait to eat here again.
author: Heinz G.

description: OMG, the food here is incredible. The beef carpaccio and shrimp pops are both great for apps and the claypot medley is my absolute favorite for dinner. I love the atmosphere here as well, the moss wall in the back reminds me of the Moss Room at the Academy of Arts and Sciences. I would give it 5 stars, but the service is still a bit lacking -- the last time we went in for dinner, our server forgot to give us menus, never refilled our water and rarely checked in -- even though the place was almost empty. I chalk it up to being relatively new and the food more than makes up for the faults in service.
author: Shelley R.

description: The plump silkenness of the grilled chicken in the rice bowl was an unexpected surprise. The quality of the chicken and the melding of flavors in that dish set it apart from your regular Vietnamese fare. Ditto the caramely, spicy crunch of their devil wings.  I'd stay away from the mango sticky rice, which was rather lackluster. I'd return for the date night level setting and service. You can actually have a conversation here without shouting!
author: Aiko S.

description:
The food here is fine - although their vegetarian choices are limited - but no better than many other Vietnamese restaurants in town to justify the high prices (double).  Perhaps as customers, we are paying for the more modern and upscale ambiance, but it really does not represent value for money.  The portions are also not at all generous - I had a starter, a main dish, and a dessert, and I went away hungry and had to snack afterwards at home.

I just dined on a saturday night, and there were plenty of empty tables, so perhaps the diners are voting for the money.
author: Patrick L.

description:
An amazing find
By all means, if you appreciate delicious Vietnamese food and excellent service, run, do not walk, to Co Nam. Recommended: Spicy Ginger cocktail; starters: quail (fabulous), calamari salad; entrées: claypot medley, basa fish claypot with jasmine rice. . .but you probably can't go wrong with just about anything on the menu. The restaurant is attractively decorated, not too noisy, and the service is attentive and smiling. It's probably not good for larger groups & I hope rowdy patrons never find it,  but if you enjoy a sophisticated meal in a charming atmosphere, this place is for you.
author: Helen P.

description: Very good Vietnamese food.  Been there twice and liked it both times.  Grilled pork roll delicious.  Lemongrass beef and prawn tomato (can't recall name) were very good.  Service is very good.  Seats are uncomforatble IMO, unless you like sitting on a board.  I wish them luck - te location has turned frequently.
author: Glenn S.

description:
Very tasty food, excited to see how this new entrant to the neighborhood develops!

Had been meaning to check out this place for a couple of months and ended up going in for a quiet Sunday lunch.  We shared some Vegetarian spring rolls, then I got the Sweet & sour basa fish soup and the boyfriend got the Pulled pork rice vermicelli.   We were both very impressed with the tasty, simple but well-balanced food.  

The food was well presented and service was attentive.  Portions were generous but manageable.  They went easy on the chilli but gave us sambal and chopped chilli peppers on the side to add according to our taste - and they were good strong chillis as I discovered when I poured a generous handful into the soup!

Oh and I'm a big fan of the delicious Genmaicha tea to wash it all down with, served in a beautiful cast iron teapot :)

Things that just stopped it getting 5 stars (for now):
At $19 each plus tip, the food was a little pricey for a lunch (especially on a street with lots of cheap lunch deals).  However, I could appreciate that it was high quality food and I wouldn't mind paying that for dinner.  
The place was pretty quiet when we were in so not feeling the ambience, though it was a nice space and well decorated.  We will have to return for dinner!

Overall, a welcome addition to the neighborhood - hope it does well and gets busier.   The food certainly merits it!
author: Katie B.

description: We really wanted to like this restaurant. The menu looked interesting as did the decor, it's not the slanted door, but it looks interesting. We enjoyed the food and the friendly service but when the bill arrived we were very disappointed. I am not exaggerating, 75% of the items were priced more on our bill than on the menu! In each case we were charged one or two dollars more that the menu price. On top of that this the restaurant adds that annoying "SF Health" charge. I just don't understand the thinking of someone opening a new restaurant and engaging in this practice. Anyone who reads the paper knows that people hate this. I can't remember a visit to a restaurant where there wasn't a discussion of this after a bill arrived with a line item adding a charge for SF Health. A restaurant owner would have to be either an idiot or so arrogant that they didn't care that this angers their patrons. The fact is, we can walk to 500 restaurants from where we live. It doesn't take much to sway our decision on where to eat. As long as the quality doesn't slip, Delfina Pizzeria can get away with a healthy SF charge, we grumble but we pay it. But a new restaurant which charges more than the menu prices? No way.
author: Lee D.

description: Absolutely brilliant! I was really surprised; walked past the restaurant and we thought 'why not?'. Food was of an exceptional standard, service appropriately attentive and I had a rare shock at the size of the check at the end (what good value it was). Highly recommended :)
author: Adam S.

description: Went on Friday night on a date. The food was very over priced and the wine was on the level you would see at a bodega. I found a very long hair in my food dish and I almost got sick right at the table. I told our server and they apologized but didn't offer me another meal. I refused to eat this dish so it just sat there until I told them to take it away. They stll charged us for the dish that was not eaten where the hair was found. I will not be back.
author: Christie S.

description: Just wonderful! My husband and I are so happy that this cozy, modern spot opened in our neighborhood. We've been twice this week. The food is delicious. It's balanced and full of flavor. My favorites so far are lemongrass chicken and claypot medley. But there are so many things on the menu that look very appealing and I need to try next time. Staff is very friendly and attentive. We are coming back next week for sure!
author: Alex G.

description: I sauntered by this place a couple of weeks ago, and didn't realize that the former Pakistani/Indian Restaurant that used to be in this spot, was no longer in business, and this new Upscale Vietnamese Restaurant had taken it's place. I was duly impressed by the aesthetics and the vibe of the place, and went in and talked to the young owner (male). I told him that I was interested in eating here, but not that particular day and could I grab some Paper Take Out menus to peruse, of which he graciously complied. I made it a "must do" thing for my next outing on Polk Street, and grabbed a friend and went there on saturday, the 30th of November. The menu offerings for an early afternoon brunch were numerous, and we settled on their version of the Thai Burger, which did not disappoint. It was so juicy and it had it's own sauce and was on some kind of a combo pretzel/potato style roll with cheese and fresh greens. Delicious! Since there were no accompaniments, we asked if we could order a side of fries, which we wanted to split. Amazingly, they split the order in the kitchen and gave us the one order on 2 separate plates. Now that is service! The fries were delicious and they had shreds of finely diced thai basil shredded over the top..Nice Touch. I asked for some salt and pepper, which the server graciously brought, but it was mixed together in one small dipping plate, which I thought a little odd, but interesting. All in all, it was a great experience and they truly (all the staff) went out of their way to make our dining experience truly memorable. I can't wait to come back and try the "true" artisan nouveau Vietnamese hand crafted plates.
author: Timothy L.

description: Really solid, got the fish clay pot and it was super tasty. Easy to get a seat on a Wednesday night
author: Ojus P.

description: We tried this place last night based on table availability and the few Yelp reviews I read. I was very pleasantly surprised. This ambiance is warm, but contemporary. All the food had a unique twist and was prepared with very fresh ingredients. The green been and shrimp salad was delicious and the fish clay pot was really good. Extensive wine and beer list won't leave you thirsty.
author: Heather W.

description: Not authentic by any means.. Tried the food for the first time and I won't be back. I left the place very hungry as they were very small portions. The wife and I both ended up eating more food at home after we left Conam. Much better options in the City if you want real Vietnamese.
author: David J.

description: Great new spot on Polk, but service wasn't steller.
author: Sierra L.

description: This place is AWESOME. My uncle dragged me here about six months ago and since then I haven't been able to get enough of Co Nam. The food is wonderful, with pretty good prices for what you get. Definitely do-able as far as dinner in the city goes! The Shaken Beef is unreal and the shrimp on the sugarcane (can't remember the exact name but comes out as an appetizer) was to die for. The ambience is awesome, cozy but definitely trendy. And the beer list blew me away. My boyfriend is a total beer snob and could NOT stop raving about all the wonderful beer they had. Priorities, right?
author: Kim K.

description: food is great.  i am sure that many people will label Co NAm as Americanised vietnamese food, but hello people, that's what makes it work.  reliability, high quality ingredients, consistent cooking, and nice presentation with discerning attention to detail is what we al should strive for in a culinary experience.  and whoever complains about prices-- c'mon, the prices are posted online.  if you want "authentic" cuisine at cut-rate prices there are plenty of places in downtown/Little Saigon that you can visit.
author: eshwar k.

description: Great decor and great food-will definitely go back. Ordered pork rolls and vermicelli, chicken clay pot and beef. All solid and flavorful.  One of the few nice looking restaurants in this town playing music with a nice loungy vibe. Don't be fooled by the negative reviews. Restaurants in sf that actually have a nice interior always get graded more harshly on food on yelp.
author: Q Q.

description: came here for a late lunch.  they close at 3:30 to prepare for their dinner service.  the food was okay. best dish that i had was the five spice chicken noodle bowl. very light, made with fresh ingredients. they have an assortment of asian beers which were $4.  beer was cheap, food was a little on the high side for what it was. i wouldn't go out of my way to go back but if you haven't been there it's worth a try.
author: Sanil S.

description: Nice interior décor and creative use of their limited space...oh and the food is pretty good too!  Been here a few times for dinner and have tried the spicy red devil wings, braised pork belly, and shrimp pops for appetizers, beef stew for soup, and the grilled five spice chicken for an entrée.  The braised pork belly was on the thicker side which I really enjoyed.  The beef shank in the beef stew was nice and tender and the French baquette that comes with the stew is great for dipping and soaking up all that stew.  They also have an interesting selection of beers and a nice assortment of wines.  The service has always been great and I definitely feel welcome and will be back again.
author: Edward Y.

description: I was initially on the fence between 4 and 5 stars...the food was excellent, the service was very good but not exceptionally speedy...but the place has a very unique and friendly vibe...which makes me really want to go back. I don't remember the name of the guy behind the bar, but his girlfriend is one of the owners and/or chefs, and he was friendly and very helpful with the drink and food menu. I think he had something to do with the interior design of the place, which is not usually something that catches my eye, but they did an incredible job with the design of this place. Awesome and unique cocktails to start off. The bun me appetizer was really flavorful, and very nicely done. I've had maybe a half a dozen others in San Francisco, and Co Nam's is my favorite by far. The tumbled beef and the fish clay pot were unanimous winners with our group. The pork chop was very good, but not our favorite. Its hardly been a week, but I'm craving this stuff already...
author: Tom C.
